DIV1.P: THE Fayre Mayde of the Exchange: With The pleasaunt Humours of the Cripple of Fanchurch.
Very delectable, and full of mirth.
LONDON Printed for HENRY ROCKIT, and are to be solde at the shop in rhe Poultrey vnder the Dyall. 1607.

DIV1.HEAD: Eleauen may easily acte this Comedie.

LIST.ITEM: Berry an old man for one.
Flower an humorous old man for one.
Ferdin. Gold. gent. and Wood. for one.
Bowdler an humo∣rous gallant. for one.
Phillis the faire Maide for one.

LG.L: THe humble Socke that true Comedians were,
Our Muse hath don'd, and to your fav'ring eyes,
In lowest Plaine-song doth her selfe appeare,
Borrowing no colours from a quaint disguise:
If your faire fauours cause her spirite to rise,
Shee to the highest pitch her wings shall reare,
And prowd quothurnicke action shall deuise,
To winne your sweete applause she deemes so deare.
Meane while shore vp our tender pamping twig,
That yet on humble ground doth lowely lie:
Your fauours sunneshine guilding once this sprig,
It may yeeld Nectar for the gods on hie:
Though our Inuention lame, imperfect be,
Yet giue the Cripple almes for charitie.

DIV1.HEAD: ¶ The faire Maide of the Exchange.
Scene. I.
DIV1.L: EVen now the welcome twilight doth salute
Th'approaching night clad in black sable weedes.
Blacke as my thoughts, that harbour nought but death,
Thefts, murthers, rapes and such like damned actes,
The infant babes to whom my soule is nurse:
Bodeth some good, the wether's faire and dry.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: My scarlet-hearted Scarlet, gallant blood,
Whose bloody deeds are worthy memorie
Of after ages, let me imbrace thee: so,
So, now me thinkes I fold a richer iemme,
Than wealthy India can afford to Spaine:
There lies my treasure, and within thy armes
Securitie that neuer breedeth harmes.

SP.SPEAKER: Scar.
SP.L: Braue resolution, I am prowde to see
So sweet a graft vpon a worm-wood tree,
Whose iuyce is gall, but yet the fruite most rare:
Who wreakes the tree, if that the fruite be faire?
Therefore resolue, if we a booty get,
It bootes not whence, from whom, when, where, or what.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: Well (God forgiue vs) heere lets take our stands,
We must haue gold although we haue no lands.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Stay Vrsula, haue you those futes of Ruffes,
Those stomachers, and that fine peece of Lawne,
Marck'd with the Letters C C. and S.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula.
SP.L: I haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: If your forgetfulnesse cause any defect,
You'r like to pay for't, therefore looke vnto it.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SP.L: I would our iourney had as safe an end,
As I am sure my Ladyes ruffes are heere,
And other wares which she bespoke of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Tis good; but stay, giue me thy hand my girle,
Tis somewhat darke, come, let vs helpe each other:
She past her word one of her gentlemen
Should meet vs at the bridge, and thats not farre,
I muse they are not come, I doe assure thee,
Were I not much beholding to her Ladiship
For many kindenesses: Mile-end, should stand
This gloomie night vnuisited for vs.
But come, me thinkes I may discerne the bridge.
And see a man or two, in very deed
Her word, her loue and all is honourable.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: A prize yong Scarlet, Oh, a gallant prize,
And we are Pirots that will seaze the same
To our owne vses.

SP.SPEAKER: Scar.
SP.L: But hold man, not too fast:
As farre as I can gather by their words,
They take vs for my Ladyes Gentlemen,
Who as it seemes should meet them on their way,
Then if thou saist the word weele seeme those men,
And by those meanes withdraw thē from their way.
Where we may rifle them of what they carry,
I meane, both goods, and their virginitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: Tis well aduisde, but Scarlet, giue me leaue
To play the Gentleman and welcome them.

SP.SPEAKER: Scar.
SP.L: Inioy thy wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: Welcome you sacred starres,
That adde bright glory to the sable night.

SP.SPEAKER: Scarl.
SP.L: Excellent, by heauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: I am sorry your beautie's so discomfited,
Treading so many tedious weary steps,
And we not present to associate you.

SP.SPEAKER: Scar.
SP.L: Oh, blessed Bobbington.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Sir, I do thanke you for this taken paines,
That as your worthy Lady promisde me,
We now inioy your wished companie.

SP.SPEAKER: Scar.
SP.L: Shee's thine owne boy, I warrant thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: And I am prowd, too prowd of this imploymēt,
Come M. Scarlet take you that pretie sweet,
You see my Ladyes care; she promisde one
But hath sent two.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Tis honourably done.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: This is your way.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: That way, alas sir no.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: Come, it is: nay then it shall be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: What meane you Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsu.
SP.L: O he will rob me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Looke to the boxe Vrsula.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil. & Vrsu.
SP.L: Helpe, helpe, murther, murther.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Now you supporters of decrepite youth,
That mount this substance twixt faire heauen and earth,
Be strong to beare that huge deformitie,
And be my hands as nimble to direct them,
As your desires to waft mee hence to London.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil. & Vrsu.
SP.L: Helpe, helpe, heele rauish me.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: My thinkes I heare the sound of rauishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil. & Vrsu.
SP.L: Helpe, helpe.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Marry and will, knew I but where, and how.
What do I see?
Theeues full of lust beset virginitie!
Now stirre thee cripple, and of thy foure legs
Make vse of one, to doe a virgin good:
Hence rauening curres: what, are you at a prey?
Will nothing satisfie your greedy chappes
But virgins flesh? Ile teach you prey on carrion, Fight & beat them away.
Packe damned rauishers, hence villaines.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Thanks, honest friend, who from the gates of death
Hath set our virgin soules at libertie.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Giue God the glory that gaue me the power.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: I do, kind Sir, and thinke my selfe much bound
To him aboue, to thee that treads this ground,
And for this aid, Ile euer honour thee;
My honor you haue sau'd redeem'd it home:
Which wer't not done, by this time had beene gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Hereafter more of this; but tell me now
The cause of these euents, the effect, and how.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Ile tell you sir; but let vs leaue this place,
And onward on our way.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: It shall be so, see where they walke along,
Ile crosse the other way and meet them full,
Keepe thou this way, and when thou hearst vs chat,
Come thou behinde him snatch away his crutches,
And then thou knowst he needs must fall to ground,
And what shall follow leaue the rest to mee. Exit. Bobb.

SP.SPEAKER: Scar.
SP.L: About it then.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Y faith she is an honourable Lady,
And I much wonder that her Ladiship
Giues intertaine to such bad men as these.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: Stand thou that hast more legs than nature gaue thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Mongrell, ile choose.

SP.SPEAKER: Scar.
SP.L: Then go to sir, you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: All, All.
SP.L: Murder murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Stay there my horse:
Whence comes this eccho of extreamitie?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Helpe, helpe.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: What doe I heare, a virgin call for helpe?
Hands off dam'nd vilaines, or by heauen I sweare,
Ile send you all to hell. Fight and driue them away.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Hold, forbeare.
I came in rescue of Virginitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: He did, he did, and freed vs once from thrall.
But now the second time they wrought his fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Now you distressed obiects, do you tell
Vpon what mount of woe your sorrowes dwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: First get we hence away, and as we goe,
Kinde gentleman, our fortunes you shall know.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Thanks worthy sir, may but the Cripple be,
Of power to gratifie this courtesie,
I then shall thinke the heauens fauour me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: No more now for Gods sake, let vs hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: If I doe liue, your loue Ile recompence. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: NOw for my true-loues hand-kercher; these flowers
Are pretie toyes, are very pretie toyes:
O but me thinkes the Peascod would doe better,
The Peascod and the Blossome, wonderfull!
Now as I liue, ile surely haue it so.
Some maides will chuse the Gilliflower, some the Rose,
Because their sweet cents do delight the nose,
But very fooles they are in my opinion,
The very worst being drawen by cunning art,
Seemes in the eye as pleasant to the heart.
But heer's the question, whether my loue or no
Will seeme content? I, there the game doth goe:
And yet ile pawne my head he will applaude
The Pescod and the flower, my pretie choice.
For what is he louing a thing in heart,
Loues not the counterfeit, though made by art?
I cannot tell how others fancie stand,
But I reioyce sometime to take in hand,
The simile of that I loue; and I protest,
That pretie pescod likes my humor best.
But ile vnto the Drawers, heele counsell me,
Heere is his shop: alas, what shall I doe?
Hee's not within, now all my labor's lost,
See, see, how forward loue is euer crost,
But stay, what Gallant's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: A plague on this Drawer, hee's neuer at home:
Good morrow sweet-heart, tell me, how thou dost?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Vpon what acquaintance?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: That's all one, once I loue thee, giue me thy hand and say, Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Hands off, sir Knaue, and weare it for a fauor.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: What? dost thou meane thy loue pretie foole?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: No foole, the knaue, O grosse;
A gentleman and of so shallow wit!

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: I know thou camst to the drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: How then?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Am not I the propperer man?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Yes, to make an asse on.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Will you get vp and ride?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: No, ile lackey by his side, and whip the asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Come, come, leaue your iesting, I shall put you down.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: With that face! away you want-wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: By this hand, I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: By the asse-head you shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Go to, you are a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Come, come, ye are a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: I haue seene as faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: I haue heard as wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: As faire as Mall Berry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: As wise as yong Bowdler.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: As M. Bowdler.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Hoida; come vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Go thou down then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: No good asse, bate an Ase of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: What M. Bowdler, will it nere be otherwise?
Still, still a hunting, euery day wenching?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Faith sir, the modest behauior of this Gentlewoman,
Hath insinuated my company.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Lord, how eloquence flowes in this Gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Faith, I shall put you downe in talke, you were best to yeeld.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: No sir, I will hold out as long as I may,
Though in the end you beare the foole away.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Meane you by me? you gull me not?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: No by this night, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: For if you did, I would intoxicate my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Yea, I dare sware you'le goe a foole to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Meane you by mee? you gull me not?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: No, I dare sweare the Gentlewoman meanes well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: And so I doe indeed, himselfe can tell:
But this it is, speake Maidens what they will,
Men are so captions the 'ile euer conster ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: To her sir, to her, I dare sware she loues you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Well then faire Mall, you loue me as you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: I neuer made you promise, did I, I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: All in good time you will do, else you lie,
Will you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: No for-sooth not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Barnard, she gulles me still.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: T'is but your mis-conceit, try her againe:
You know by course all women must be coy;
To her againe, then she may happely yeeld.
Not I, in faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Then mine shall be the field:
Wisedome, adue, once more faint heart farewell;
Yet if thou seest the Drawer, I prethee tell him,
Mall Berry hath more worke for him to doe;
And for your selfe, learne this when you doe woe,
Arme you with courage, and with good take heede,
For he that spares to speake must spare to speede,
And so farewell. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Call her againe, Barnard.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: Shee's too swift for me:
Why this is the right course of gullerie,
What did you meane hauing so faire an aime
So fondly to let slip so faire a game?
Bowdler become a man for maides will stand,
And then strike home, art thou not yong and lustie,
The minion of delight, faire from thy birth,
Adonis play-pheere, and the pride of earth?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: I know it, but a kind of honest blood
Tilts in my loynes, with wanton appetites,
She bade me doe a message to the Drawer,
And I will doe it; there will come a day,
When Humfry Bowdler, will keepe holiday,
Then Mall looke to your selfe, see that you be sped,
Or by this light Ile haue your maidenhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Larn.
SP.L: Spoke like a gallant, spoke like a gentleman, spoke like your selfe:
Now doe I see some sparkes of manhoode in you,
Keepe in that key, keepe in the selfe same song,
Ile gage my head youle haue her loue ere long. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Wilt thou not tell me (brother Ferdinand)
Now by this light Ile haunt thee like a sprite,
Vntill I know whence springs this melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: O brother!
Thou art too yong to reach the depth of griefe,
That is immur'd within my hearts deepe closet,
A thousand sighes keepe daily centinell,
That beate like whirle-winds all my comfort backe,
As many sobbes guard my distressed heart,
That no reliefe comes neere to ayde my soule,
Millions of woes like bands of armed men,
Stop vp the passage of my sweete reliefe:
And arte thou then perswaded that thy wordes,
Can any comfort to my soule afford?
No, no, good Franke, deere brother then forbeare,
Vnlesse with griefe in me youle take a share.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Griefe me no griefes, but tell me what it is
Makes my (sweete Ferdinand) thus passionate:
Ile coniure griefe, if griefe be such an euill,
In spite of Fortnne, Fates, or any Deuill.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Wilt thou not leaue me to my selfe alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Brother, you know my minde,
If you will leaue your dumpish melancholy,
And like my selfe banish that puling humour,
Or satisfie my exspectation,
By telling whence your sorrow doth proceede
I will not onely cease to trouble you,
But like a true skilfull phisition,
Seeke all good meanes for your recouerie.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Well brother, you haue much importun'd me,
And for the confidence I haue in you,
That youle proue secret, I will now vnfold,
The loade of care that presseth downe my soule:
Know then good Franke, loue is tke cause hereof.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: How, loue! why whats that loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: A child, a little little boy thats blind.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: And be ore-come by him! plagude by him!
Driuen into dumps by him! put downe by a boy!
Master'd by loue! O, I am mad for anger:
By a Boy! is there no rosemary and bayes in England
To whip the Ape? by a boy!

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I, such a boy as thou canst neuer see,
And yet ere long mayst feele his tirranie:
Hee's not visible, yet aimes at the heart,
Wo be to those that feele his wounding dart;
And one of them I am: wounded so deepe,
That in my passions I no meane can keepe:
Vnhappy time, woe to that dismall howre,
When loue did wound me with faire Phillis flowre:
O Phillis, Phillis; of flowers sweetest flower,
That euer garnish'd any princely bowre:
Farewell, farewell, my woes will ne're remoue,
Till I inioy faire Phillis for my loue. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Whats heere, Phillis and loue, and loue and Phillis:
I haue seene Phillis, and haue heard of loue;
I will see Phillis, and will heare of loue:
But neither Phillis, nor the power of loue,
Shall make me bond-slaue to a womans becke.
Who's here, my second brother male-content?
Ile stand aside and note his passions.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: O loue, that I had neuer knowne thy power.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: More louers yet! what the deuill is this loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: That these my wandring eyes had kept their stay;
That I my selfe had still beene like my selfe;
That my poore heart had neuer felt the wound,
Whose anguish keepes me in a deadly sound:
Oh how deluding dreames this night ore-past,
Drench'd my sad soule in pleasures floting sea!
Me thought I clasp'd my loue within my armes,
And circling her, sau'd her from threatning harmes;
Me thought there came an hundred in an houre
That sought to rob me of my sweetest flower:
But like a champion I did keepe her still
Within this circle, free from euery ill:
But when I wak'd and missd my Phillis there,
All my sweete ioyes conuerted into feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: What brother Anthony, at praiers so hard?
Tell me what saint it is thou inuocates?
Is it a male, or female? howsoeuer,
God blesse thee brother, th'art in a good mind,
But now I remember me, thy saint is blind.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: How, blind?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I brother, blind, I heard thee talke of loue,
And loue is blind they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: I would it were as blinde as Ebon night,
That loue had neuer hit my heart so right;
But what is loue in your opinion?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: A voluntary motion of delight,
Touching the superficies of the soule;
A substance lesse diuine then is the soule,
Yet more then any other power in man
Is that which loues, yet neither is enforc'd,
Nor doth enforce the heart of man to loue:
Which motion as it vnbeseemes a man,
So by the soule and reason which adorne,
The life of man it is extinguished,
Euen at his pleasure that it doth possesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Thus may the free-man iest at mannacles,
The furre-clad citizen laugh at a storme,
The swartie Moore diuing to gather pearle,
Challenge the scalding ardor of the sunne;
And aged Nestor sitting in his tent,
May tearme wounds sport, & warre but merriment.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Tis true, fore God it is, and now me thinks,
My heart begins to pittie hearts in loue:
Say once more, Anthony, tell me thy griefes,
Let me haue feeling of my passion,
Possesse me deeply of thy melting state,
And thou shalt see.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: That thou wilt pittie me,

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: No by my troth, if euery tale of loue,
Or loue it selfe, or foole-bewitching beautie,
Make me crosse-arme my selfe; studdy ay-mees;
Defie my hat-band; tread beneath my feete
Shoo-strings and garters; practise in my glasse
Distressed lookes, and dry my liuer vp,
With sighes enough to win an argosie.
If euer I turne thus fantastical,
Loue plague me, neuer pittie me at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Yonder she comes that holds me prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: What? Phillis, the faire maid of the Exchange?
Is she god Cupids iudge ouer mens hearts?
Brother, ile haue one venny with her tongue,
To breathe my wit, and iest at passion:
By your leaue Mistresse Flower.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Your rude behauiour scarse offers you welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I prethee tell me Phillis, I heare say,
Thou keepst loue captiue in thy maiden thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: That is a thought beyond your reach to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: But shall I know it?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: On what acquaintance? then might you deeme mee fond,
If (as you say) loue be at my command.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: May not your friend command as great a matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Ile know him well first, for that friend may flatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Why, I hope you know me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: That's a question.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Well, if you doe not, you shall before I stirre.
Know you yonder lump of melancholie,
Yonder bundle of sighes yonder wad of grones,
The same and I were chickins of one broode,
And if you know him, as I am sure you doe,
Being his brother, you needes must know me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: I partly haue a guesse of yonder Gentleman,
His name is Maister Golding as I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Golding I am, and thine sweete faire I am,
And yet not thine, but a most wretched man,
Thou knowst my cause of griefe, my wound of woe:
And knowing it, why wilt thou see it so?
Put salues of comfort to my griefes vnrest,
So maist thou heale my sore of heauinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Hearke you faire maide, are you a Surgeon?
I prethee giue my brother Anthony
Somewhat to heale the loue sore of his mind,
And yet tis pitty that he should haue help:
A man as free as aire, or the Sunnes raies,
As boundlesse in his function as the heauens,
The male and better part of flesh and blood,
In whom was powrde the quintessence of reason,
To wrong the adoration of his Maker,
By worshipping a wanton female skirt,
And making Loue his Idoll: fie dotard, fie,
I am ashamde of this apostacie,
Ile talke with her to hinder his complaints.
Phillis, a word in priuate ere you goe,
I loue yee sweete.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Sowre, it may be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Sowre, and sweete; faith that doth scarce agree.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Two contraries, and so be we.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: A plague on this courting, come, weele make an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: I am sory for it since you seeme my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: I, but thou canst not weepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Then had I a hard heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: How say you? come brother, now to your part.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: At your direction: no, this merry glee,
(Good brother) sortes not with my melancholie,
Loue couets priuate conference, so my sorrow,
Craueth your absence which I faine would borrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Franck.
SP.L: No maruell then we say that loue is blind,
If it still reuell in obscurity,
I will depart I will not hinder loue,
Ile wash my handes fare well sweet turtle doue. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Yfaith your brother is a proper man.

SP.SPEAKER: Franck.
SP.L: Whats your will with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Euen what you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Franck.
SP.L: Did you not call me backe?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Not, to my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Franck.
SP.L: No, sbloud somewhat did, farewell, farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: He is a very very proper man.

SP.SPEAKER: Franck.
SP.L: I am in haste pray vrge me not to stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: The man doth dote pray God he hits his way.

SP.SPEAKER: Franck.
SP.L: Fore God ther's not a maide in all this towne,
Should sooner winne me, but my busines calls me,
Giue me thy hand, next time I meete with thee,
Lesser intreaty shall wooe my company.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Yfaith yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Franck.
SP.L: Yfaith, this was the hand, what meanes my bloud,
Doe I not blush, nor looke extreamely pale?
Is not my head a fire, my eyes nor heart?
Ha, art thou here? I feele thee loue I faith,
By this light, well via farewell, farewell. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.L: Now he is gonne, and we in priuate talke,
Say, wilt thou graunt me loue, wilt thou be mine?
For all the interest in my loue is thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Your brother Ferdinand hath vowd as much,
Na more, he sweres what man so ere he be,
Presumes to be corriuall in his loue,
He will reuenge it as an iniurie,
And clothe the theefe in basest obloquie.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.L: I, is my brother my competitor?
Ile court my loue and will solicite thee,
Were Ferdinand himselfe in company.
What saist thou to my sute?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil
SP.L: Time may doe much, what I intend to doe
I meane to pawse vpon.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Let it be so;
If that my brothers hinderance be all,
Ile haue thy loue though by my brothers fall. Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Two brothers drownd in loue, I and the third
For all his outward habite of neglect,
If I iudge rightly if I did not dreame,
Hath dipt his foote too in Loues scalding streame.
Well, let them pleade and perish if they will;
Cripple, my heart is thine, and shall be still. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: I am not well, and yet I am not ill,
I am, what am I? not in loue I hope?
SP.P:
In loue! let me examine my selfe, who should I loue? who did I last conuerse with, with Phillis: why should I loue Phillis? is she faire? faith so so: her forehead is pretty, somewhat re∣sembling the forehead of the signe of the maiden head in, &c. Whats her haire? faith to Bandora wiars, theres not the like simile: is it likely yet that I am in loue? Whats next? her cheekes, they haue a reasonable scarlet, never a Diars daughter in the towne goes beyond her. Well, yet I am not in loue. Nay, she hath a mole in her cheeke too: Venus mole was not more naturall; but what of that, I am Adonis, and will not loue. Good Venus pardon me. Let vs descend: her chinne, O Helen, Helen, wheres your dimple Helen? it was your dimple that bewitcht Paris, and without your dimple I will not loue you Helen, No, yet I am safe. Her hand, lettes handle that, I sawe her hand, and it was lilly white, I toucht her palme, and it was soft and smoothe: and then what then? her hand did then bewitch me, I shall be in loue now out of hand. In loue! shall I that euer yet haue prophand loue, now fall to worship him? Shall I that haue ieasted at louers sighes now raise whirle windes? shall I that haue flowted ay-mees once a quarter, now practise ay-mees euery minute? shall I de∣fie hat-bands, and treade garters and shoostrings vnder my feete? shall I fall to falling bands and be a ruffin no longer? I must; I am now liege man to Cupid, and haue read all these informations in his booke of statutes, the first chapter, page millesimo nono, therefore, hat-band avaunt, ruffe regard your
selfe, garters adue, shoo-strings so and so; I am a poore en∣amorate, and enforcde with the Poet to say, Loue orecomes all, and I that loue obey. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.L: Now afore God a very good conceit,
But too much sleepe hath ouer taken me,
The night hath plaid the swift-foote runne-away:
A good conceit, a very good conceit,
What Fiddle, arise Fiddle, Fiddle I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Heer's a fidling indeed, I thinke your tongue be made of nothing but fiddlestrings, I hope the fiddle must haue some rest as well as the fiddle-sticke: well Crowde, what say you to Fiddle now?

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.P: Fiddle, it is a very good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: It is indeed, Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.P: What dost thou meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: To goe to bed againe Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.P: No, Fiddle, that were no good conceit Fiddle,

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: What a fidling doe you keepe, are you not ashamde to make such musicke; I hope sir, you will christen mee anew shortly, for you haue so worne this name, that ne're a wench in all the towne but will scorne to dance after my fiddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.P: Well Fiddle, thou art an honest fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Thats more than you know, Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.P: Ile sweare for thee Fiddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Youle be damn'd then, Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.P: I loue thee Fiddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: I had rather your daughter lou'd me,

SP.SPEAKER: Elow,
SP.P: Tis a rare conceit ifaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: I hold with you Master, if my yong mistresse would like so well of my musicke, that she would dance after no bo∣dies instrument but mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.P: No Fiddle, that were no good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: A shame on you, I thought you would not heare on that side

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.P: Fiddle, thou toldst me, M. Golding was in loue with my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: True, master; therin you say well.

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.P: And he intreats me to meet him at the starre in cheap, to talke concerning the match.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.P: True still maister.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: And I haue sent for my neighbour M. Berry to beare me company,

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.P: True, all this is most naturall truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: And now Fiddle, I am going on my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.P: Nay thats a lie, that hath marrd all, was your con∣ceipt so tirde you could tel troth no longer?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Why Fiddle, are we not going?

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.P: No indeede sir, we are not, we stand still, your con∣ceit failde in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Fore God tis true, I am not ready yet: whats hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.P: By your leaue sir, I would craue a word in secret sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: At your pleasure, heeres none but my man Fiddle,

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.P: I sir, maister Fiddle is my name, sir Laurence Syro was my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.P: Sir, this is my businesse, my name is Racket, I haue a ship of my owne vpon the riuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: By your leaue sir, captaine Racket is your name.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.P: Some call me so indeede sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: It is a good conceit, I pray proceede.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.P: Sir, I am now bound to sea, and wanting some monie for the better furnishing of my wants.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: O, you would borrow mony of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.P: Thats my sute indeede.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Thats no good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.P: Na, heare me sir, if you wil supply me with ten pound til my returne from Barbary, I will leaue in your hands a dia∣mond of greater value than the mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: A Diamond, is it a Diamond, or but a counterfet?
Fiddle, my spectacles.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: Tis right, I assure you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Then tis a good conceit: my spectacles.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.L: Heere sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: Where sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.L: You cannot see maister, but I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: O tis good, it is a good conceit: wel sir, tenne pound,
You are content if at three months end,
You bring me not ten pound in English coine,
This diamond shall be my proper owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: I am sir, shall I receiue the money now?

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.L: I, heere it is, and tis a good conceit.
Will you goe neere sir? Fiddle, make him drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.L: Will you approch caualiero, if I speake not in sea∣son, tis because I was neuer in the salt country, where you sea captaines vse to march.

SP.SPEAKER: Bob.
SP.L: You are very eloquent sir, ile follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.L: Let me alone then for leading my men.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: A diamond worth forty for tenne pound,
If he returne not safe from Barbarie,
Tis good, a very good conceit. Enter M. Berry.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: By your leaue maister Flower.

SP.SPEAKER: Flow.
SP.L: Welcome good maister Berry, I was bold to intreat your company to speake with a friend of mine,
It is some trouble, but the conceit is good.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: No trouble at all sir, shall we be going?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.L: With all my heart sir, and as we goe,
Ile tell you my conceit, come maister Berry. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter at one doore Cripple, at the other Bowdler.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Well met my deere bundle of rew, well met.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: As much to thee my humorous blossome.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: A plague on thee for a dog, haue I found thee? I hate thee not, and yet by this hand I could finde in my heart: but sirra, Crutch, I was encountred.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: Who became your baile?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Ye filthy dog, I was encountred by a wench I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: In a wenches counter! I thought no lesse: what sirra didst thou lie in the Knights warde, or on the maisters side?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Neither, neither yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: Where then, in the Hole?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: By this hand Cripple ile bombaste thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: My crutch you meane for wearing out my clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P:
Thy nose dogge, thy nose, a plague on thee, I care not for thee, and yet I cannot choose but loue thee.
Sirra, Mall Berry was heere about woorke thou hast of hers, hadst thou been here to haue heard how I spurrd the wench with incantations, thou wouldst haue giuen me the praise for a jeaster.

SP.SPEAKER: Cripple
SP.P: True maister Bowdler, I yeelde it you, I holde you for the absolutst jeaster; O mis-take me not, I meane to jest vpon, a juggling gull, a profound seeing man of shallow wit, that Europe, na the world I thinke affords.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Well, thou art a Iew sirra, Ile cut out that venomous tongue of thine one of these dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cripple
SP.P: Doe it in time, or Ile crush the heart of thy wit till I haue straind foorth thy infectious humour to a drop yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Heere comes my amorous vessell, ile boorde her y∣faith: Well encountred Mall, how doost thou wench, how doost thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.P: Whats that to you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Why I aske thee in kindnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Why then in kindenes you are a foole for asking.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Is the foole your liuerie?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Not so, for then you wearing that liuerie, woulde terme your selfe my foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Meaning me? you gull me not, if you doe:

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: O vile! I woud take you downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Alas it wants wit, his wit is too narrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowdler
SP.P: Ile stretch my wit but I will take you downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: How, vpon the tenters? indeede if the whole peece were so stretcht, and very well beaten with a yeard of refor∣mation, no doubt it would grow to a goodly breadth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: By this hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Away you asse, hinder not my businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: Finely put off wench yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: By your leaue maister Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cripple
SP.P: Welcome mistris Berry, I haue beene mindefull of your worke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Is it done?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: Yes, and heere it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Heere is your money.
Cripple, ere long ile visit thee againe,
I haue some ruffes and stomachers to drawe.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: At your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: By thy leaue Mall, a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: Away you bundle of nothing, away. Exit Mal.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: She hath a wit as sharpe as her needle.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowdler
SP.P: Alas, my selfe haue beene her whetstone with my conference in th'Exchange any time these many yeares.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: In th'Exchange! I haue walkt with thee there, before the visitation of my legges, and my expence in timber, at the least a hundred times, and neuer heard thee speak to a wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Thats a lie, thou wert by when I bought these gloues of a wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Cripple.
SP.P: Thats true, they cost thee an English shilling at a word, mary it followes in the text, that your shilling proou'd but a harper, and thou wert shamefully arraignd for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Good, but I excusde my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: True, that thou thoughtst it had bin a shilling, ma∣ry thou hadst neuer an other, nor so much as a shilling more to change it. Thou talke in th'Exchange!

SP.SPEAKER: Bowdler
SP.P: Indeede my best gift is in the morning when the Maides visite my chamber, with such necessaries as I vsually buy of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: O thou art one of those, that if an honest Maid be sent to thy chamber with her Mistris goodes, and returne as honest and chaste as the moone: Sirra, you are one of those that will slaunder the poore wenches, by speaking liberally of their pronenesse to loue; and withall, bragge how cheap you haue bought their ware metaphorically, when indeede they depart as honest as they came thither, and leaue you all the day after to sigh at the sight of an ill bargaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.P: When wilt thou spit out this serpents tong of thine?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: When wilt thou cast off this anticke garment of o∣stentation? do it, do it, or by the Lord I wil impresse thy va∣nities, and so anotomize the very bowells of thy absurdities, that all the worlde shall take notice of thee for a foole, and shunne thee as the pox or the pestilence.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: Newes, newes, newes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Sweete rogue, whats the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: By Iesu the rarest dauncing in christendome.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Sweet rascall, where, O doe not kill my soule
With such delayes, tell me kinde rogue, O tell me where it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: At a wedding in Gratious streete.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Come, come, away, I long to see the man
In dauncing Arte that does more than I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Than you sir! he liues not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Why I did vnderstand thee so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You onely excepted, the world besides
Cannot afford more exquisite dauncers
Than are now capring in that bridale house.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: I will beholde them, come crutch, thou shalt with vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Downe dogge, ile haue thy company.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: I haue businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: By this hand thou shalt goe with vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: By this leg I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: A lame othe, neuer stand to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: By this crutch but I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Come, you loose time, supper is done long since,
And they are now a dauncing.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: Stay Fiddle with thy torch, Gentlemen, good eeuen.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: Maister Berry!

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Maister Berry, I wish you well sir: maister Fiddle I am yours for a congee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.L: After the French salutation I am yours for the like curtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: Maister Barnard, to morrow is your day
Of payment sir, I meane the hundred pound,
For which I haue your bond, I know tis sure,
You will not breake an houre; then if you please
To come to dinner sir, you shall be welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: Sir, I did meane to visite you at home,
Not to pay downe the money, but intreate
Too moneths for-bearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: How! forbeare my money?
Your reason, why I should forbeare my owne?

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: You know at first the debt was none of mine,
I was a suretie, not the principall:
Besides, the money that was borrowed
Miscarried in the venture; my friend died,
And once already haue you prisoned me,
To my great charge, almost my ouer-throw,
And some-what raisde the debt by that aduantage:
These things considered, you may well forbeare
For two moneths space, so small a summe as this.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: How! I may forbeare; Sir, I haue neede of money:
I may indeed sit monilesse at home,
And let you walke abroad spending my coyne.
This I may doe, but sir you know my minde,
If you do breake your day, assure your selfe,
That I will take the forfeit of your bond.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: The forfeit of his bond!

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: I sir, the forfeit; tis no charitie
To fauour you that liue like Libertines:
Heer's a Crew!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: A crew; what Crew?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: A crew of vnthrifts, carelesse dissolutes,
Licencious prodigalls, vilde tauern-tracers.
Night watching money-wasters, what should I call yee?
O I want words for to define you rightly;
But this I know, London ne're fostred such
As Barnard, Bowdler, and this paltrie crutch.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: And you want words sirra, ile teach thee words;
Thou shouldst haue come to euery one of vs
As thus: thou wretch, thou miser thou vilde slaue
And drudge to money, bond-man to thy wealth,
Apprentice to a penny, thou that hourds vp
The frie of siluer pence and half-penies,
With shew of charitie to giue the poore,
But putst them to increase, where in short time
They grow a childs part, or a daughters portion.
Thou that inuents new clauses for a bond
To cousin simple plainenesse: O not a Dragon,
No, nor the deuils fangs are halfe so cruell
As are thy clawes; thus, thus thou shouldst haue railde:
The forfeit of his bond, O I could spit
My heart into his face; thou blood-hound that dost hunt
The deere, deere life of noble Gentrie.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry.
SP.L: Cripple, tis knowne I am an honest man;
But for thy wordes, Barnard shall fare the worse:
As for thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Who he sir, neuer regard him, I know the vildest thing by him, O tis abhominable!

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Dost thou so Fiddle, speake, hold, take thou that speake of his shame, speake freely, ile protect thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: I tell you sir, twill make your haire to stand on end as stiffe as a Rubbing-brush, to heare his villanies.
What's this you haue giuen me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: A shilling Fiddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Haue you any skill in Arithmeticke?

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Why dost thou aske?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Sir, I would haue you to multiply; could you not make this one shilling two or three? I would not be knowne to beg, but if out of your cunning you can doe this tricke of multi∣plication, I shall speake the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: O ther's another shilling for thee, now let mee heare what villanies thou canst charge the Cripple with.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: So sir, this is multiplication, now sir, if you know the Rule of addition you are an excellent Scholler: can you not adde?

SP.SPEAKER: Berry.
SP.L: What dost thou meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: An other shilling sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: There is another shilling; now Fiddle speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Why then attend you Hilles and Dales, and stones so quicke of hearing, this Cripple is.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: What is he villaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: An honest man, as any is in all the towne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: An honest man!

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L:
I by this siluer, and as good a fellow as euer went vp∣on
foure legges, if you would multiply till mid-night, I would neuer speake otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: Fiddle, thou art a knaue, and so is hee:
Come let vs home; Barnard, looke to thy bond,
If thou doe breake thy day, I do protest,
By yon chaste Moone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: The chaste Moone, why the Moone is not chaste.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: How prou'st thou that?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Why sir, ther's a man in the middle of her, how can she be chaste then?

SP.SPEAKER: Berr.
SP.L: Then by my life I sweare, ile clap him vp
Where he shall see neither the sunne nor moone,
Till I be satisfied the vtmost penny,
And so fare-well. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Gallants good-night; if time and place were in pros∣peritie, I were yours for an houres societie, I must after yon mulbery with my torch: adue deare hearts, adue. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Come Barnard, lets to the dancing, lets tickle it to night, For to morrow thy heeles may be too heauy.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: Alls one; my heart shall be as light as fire.
Come, shall we goe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Cripple, will you along?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: My busines stayes me heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Fare-well then dogge of Israell, farewell. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Als one, my heart shall be as light as fire:
Sblood, were I endebted a hundred pound,
My fortune faild, and fled as Barnards are,
Not worth a hundred pence as Barnards is:
I shoud be now deuising sentences
And Caueats, for posteritie to carue
Vpon the inside of the counter wall:
Therefore Ile now turne prouident; Ile to my shoppe
And fall to worke.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Yonder's his shop, O now you gods aboue
Pittie poore Phillis heart, that melts in loue;
Instruct the Cripple to finde out my loue,
Which I will shadow vnder the conceit
Of my inuention for this piece of worke;
O teach him how to yeeld me loue againe,
A little little loue, a dramme of kinde affection,
His many vertues are my true direction:
By your leaue M. Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Welcome Mistresse Flower, whats your pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: My cause of comming is not vnknowne to you,
Here is be spoken worke which must be wrought
With expedition, I pray haue care of it;
The residue I referre to your direction:
Onely this hankercher, a yong Gentlewoman,
Wishd me acquaint you with her mind herein:
In one corner of the same, place wanton loue,
Drawing his bow shooting an amorous dart,
Opposite against him an arrow in a heart,
In a third corner picture foorth disdaine,
A cruell fate vnto a louing vaine:
In the fourth drawe a springing Lawrell tree,

Circled about with a ring of poesie: and thus it is:
Loue wounds the heart and conquers fell disdayne,
Loue pitties loue, seeing true loue in paine:
Loue seeing Loue how faithfull Loue did breath,
At length impalà loue with a Laurell wreath.
Thus you haue heard the Gentle-womans minde,
I pray be carefull that it be well done:
And so I leaue you, more I faine would say,
But shame forbids and calles me hence away. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Sweet faire, I pittie, yet no reliefe
Harbors within the closet of my soule:
This Phillis beares me true affection,
But I detest the humor of fond loue:
Yet am I hourely solicited
As now you see, and faine she would make knowne
The true perplexion of her wounded heart:
But modestie checking her forwardnesse
Bids her be still; yet she in similies
And loue-comparisons, like a good Scholler
By figures makes a demonstration
Of the true loue enclosed in her heart.
I know it well, yet will not tell her so,
Fancie shall neuer marry me to woe;
Take this of me, a yong man's neuer mar'd,
Till he by marriage from all ioy be bar'd. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Yo gods of Loue that sits aboue, and pitty Louers paine,
Looke from your thrones vpon the mones, that I do now sustaine.
Was euerman thus tormented with loue?

LG.HEAD: Song.
LG.L: Ye little birds that sit and sing
Amidst the shadie valleys,
And see how Phillis sweetly walkes
Within her Garden alleyes;
Goe pretie birds about her bowre,
Sing pretie birdes she may not lowre,
Ah me, me thinkes I see her frowne
Ye pretie wantons warble.
Go tell her through your chirping billes,
As you by me are bidden,
To her is onely knowne my loue,
Which from the world is hidden:
Goe prety birds and tell her so,
See that your notes straine not too low,
For still me thinke I see her frowne,
Ye pretie wantons warble.
Go tune your voices harmonie,
And sing I am her Louer;
Straine lowde and sweet, that euery note,
With sweet content may moue her:
And she that hath the sweetest voyce,
Tell her I will not change my choice,
Yet still me thinkes I see her frowne,
Ye pretie wantons warble.
O flie, make haste, see, see she falles
Into a prety slumber,
Sing rownd about her rosie bed
That waking she may wonder,
Say to her, tis her louer true,
That sendeth loue to you to you:
And when you heare her kinde reply,
Returne with pleasant warblings.

SP.L: Auaunt delusion, thoughts cannot winne my loue;
Loue, though diuine, cannot diuine my thoughts:
Why to the ayre then do I idle heere
Such heedles words farre off, and ne're the neere;
Hie thee yong Franke, to her that keepes thy heart,
There let sweet words they sweeter thoughts impart.
But stay; here comes my mellancholly brothers both,
Ile step aside, and heare their conference. Exit aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.L: What? is my brother Ferdinand so neere?
He is my elder, I must needs giue place;
Anthony, stand by, and list what he doth say,
Haste calles me hence, yet I will brooke delay.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Shall I exclaime gainst fortune and mishap.
Or raile on Nature who first framed me?
Is it hard chance that keepes me from my loue?
Or is this heape of loathd deformitie,
The cause that breeds a blemmish in her eye?
I know not what to thinke, or what to say,
Onely one comfort yet I haue in store,
Which I will practise though I ne're try more.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Oh, for to heare that comfort I doe long,
Ile turne it to a straine to right my wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I haue a brother riuall in my loue;
I haue a brother hates me for my loue;
I haue a brother vowes to winne my loue;
That brother too, he hath incenst my loue,
To gaine the beauty of my deerest loue;
What hope remaines then to inioy my loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: I am that brother riuall in his loue,
I am that brother hates him for his loue:
Not his but mine, and I will haue that loue,
Or neuer liue to see him kisse my loue;
What thou erst sayd, I am that man alone,
That will depose you brother from loues throne;
I am that man, though you my elder be,
That will aspire beyond you one degree.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I haue no meanes of priuate conference,
So narrowly pursues my hinderer,
No sooner am I entred the sweet court
Of louely rest, my loues rich mansion,
But riuall loue to my affection
Followes me, as a soone enforced strawe,
The drawing vertue of a sable jeat:
This therefore's my determination,
Within the close wombe of a sealed paper,
Will I right downe in bloody Characters,
The burning zeale of my affection:
And by some trusty messenger or other,
Conuey the same into my loues owne hand;
So shall I know her resolution,
And how she fancies my affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.L: Yet subtill Fox, I may perchance to crosse you:
Brother, well met; whither away so fast?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: About affaires that doe require some haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.L: Tis well done brother, you seeke still for gaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: But you would reape the haruest of my paine:
Farewell good brother, I must needes be gone,
I haue serious businesse now to thinke vpon:
Yet for I feare my brother Anthonie,
Ile step aside and stand a while vnseene,
I may perchance discry which way he goes;
Thus policie must worke twixt friends and foes. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: So, hee is gone, I scarsely trust him neither;
For tis his custome, like a sneaking foole,
To fetch a compasse of a mile about,
And creepe where he would be; well, let him passe,
I heard him say, that since by word of mouth
He could not purchase his sweet mistresse fauour,
He would endeuour what his wit might doe
By writing, and by tokens; O tis good
Writing with inke; O no, but with his blood.
Well, so much for that, now I know his minde
I doe intend not to be farre behinde:
Heele send a letter, I will write another,
Doe what you can, ile be before you brother;
Ile entercept his letter by the way,
And as time serues, the same I will bewray:
Mine being made, a Porter Ile procure,
That shall conuey that heart-inticing lure;
About it then, my letter shall be writ,
Though not with blood, yet with a reaching wit. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: And shall it so, good brother Anthonie?
Were you so neere when we in secret talk'd?
Wilt ne're be otherwise? will you dog me still?
Welcome sweete Frank; such news I haue to tell,
As cannot chuse but like thee passing well:
Thou knowest my loue to Phillis?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Brother, say on.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Thou likewise art acquainted with my riuall,
And I doe build vpon your secrecie.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Sblood, and I thought you did not, Ide retire:
Brother you know, I loue you as my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I dare professe as much, and there-vpon
Make bold to craue thy furtherance, in a thing
Concernes me much.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke.
SP.L: Out with it brother;
If I shrinke backe, repose trust in some other.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Then thus it is; my brother all in haste
Is gone, to write a letter to my loue,
And thinkes thereby to crosse me in my sute,
Sending it by a Porter to her hand;
If euer therefore thou wilt aid thy brother,
Helpe me in this, who seekes helpe from no other.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: By the red lippe of that daintie saint, Ile aid thee all I may.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: It is enough; then brother Ile prouide
A Porters habite, alike in euery point,
Will you but so much humble your estate,
To put your selfe in that so base attyre,
And like so meane a person waite his comming,
About his doore which will not be ore long,
Thou shalt for euer binde me to thy loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Brother, tis a base taske, by this light,
But to procure a further force of loue,
Ile doot, yfaith I will sweete Ferdinand,
About it then, prouide thee some disguise,
But see you stay not long in any wise,
Heere shall you finde me, goe, dispatch.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: For this ile loue thee euerlastingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Meane time ile crosse your loue and if I can.
Heeres no villanie twixt vs three brothers:
My brother Ferdinand he would haue the wench,
And Anthonie he hopes to haue her too:
Then what may I? faith hope well, as they doe.
Neither of them know that I loue the Maide;
Yet by this hand I am halfe mad for loue.
I know not well what loue is, but tis sure,
Ile die if I haue her not, therefore
Good brothers mine beguile you one an other,
Till you be both gulld by your yonger brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Heere is a Porters habite, on with it brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.L: Your hand then brother for to put it on,
So now tis well, come brother, whats my taske?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: This first, that thou make haste to Anthonies,
Aske for a burden and thou shall be sure
To haue his letter to my deere loue Phillis,
Deliuer it not, but keepe it to thy selfe,
Till thou hast giuen this paper to her hands,
Whose lines do intimate thy chaste desires.
This is the summe of all, good Franke, make haste,
Loue burnes in me, and I in loue doe waste. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Waste still, but let me in my loue increase,
Now would not all the world take me for a Porter?
How strangely am I metamorphosed?
And yet I neede not be ashamed neither,
Ioue when his loue-scapes when he attempted euer
Transformd himselfe, yet euer sped in loue,
Why may not I then in this strange disguise?
This habite may prooue mighty in loues powre,
As beast, or bird, bull, or swanne, or golden showre.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.L: Within the centre of this paper square,
Haue I wrote downe in bloudy characters,
A pretty poesie of a wounded heart,
Such is loues force once burst into a flame,
Doe what we can we cannot quench the same,
Vnlesse the teares of pitty moue compassion,
And so quench out the fire of affection,
Whose burning force heats me in euery vaine,
That I to Loue for safety must complaine:
This is my Orator whose dulcet tongue
Must pleade my loue to beauteous Phillis.
Now for a trusty messenger to be
Imployd heerein betwixt my loue and me,
And in good time I see a Porter nie,
Come hither fellow, dwellst thou heere about?

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Sir, my abiding is not farre from hence,
And Trusty Iohn men call me by my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Canst thou be trusty then, and secret too,
Being imployd in weighty businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Sir, I was neuer yet disproou'd in eyther.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Then marke me well, in Cornhill by th'Exchange,
Dwells an old Merchant, Flower they call his name,
He hath one onely daughter, to whose hands,
If thou conueniently canst giue this letter,
Ile pay thee well, make thee the happiest Porter
That euer vndertooke such businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Sir, giue me your letter, if I doe it not,
Then let your promisde fauour be forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Anthony Golding is my name, my friend,
About it then, thy message being done,
Make haste to me againe, till when, I leaue thee. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: And so fare thee well louing brother,
It had bin better you had sent some other,
Let me consider what is best be done,
Shall I deliuer his letter? No:
Shall I conuey it to my riuall brother? Nor so:
Shall I teare the same? No not for a million:
What shall I then do? mary like a kinde brother,
Open the booke, see what is written there,
If nought but loue, in loue haue thou a share.
Brother, by your leaue I hope youle not deny,
But that I loue you: God blesse my eie-sight,
A Sonnet tis in verse, now on my life
He hath perusde all the impressions
Of Sonnets since the fall of Lucifer,
And made some scuruy quaint collection
Of fustian phrases, and vplandish wordes.

LETTER.HEAD: A Letter.
LETTER.L: FAire glory of vertue, thy enamorate
Whose passion Loue do thou exonorate,
And he shall liue by thy protection:
Nor from thy loue shall he once derogate,
For any soule vnder this horizon,
Yeeld thou to loue, and I will faile in neither,
So loue and truth shall alwayes liue together.

SP.L: Before God, excellent good Poetry,
Sbloud what meanes he by this line?
For any soule vnder this horizon?
No matter for his meaning, meane what he will,
I meane his meaning shall not be deliuered,
But for my other trust my other letter,
That shall come short too of faire Phillis hands,
There is a Cripple dwelling heere at hand,
Thats very well acquainted with the Maide,
And for I once did rescue them from thieues,
Swore, if he liude, he would requite that kindnes,
To him I will for councell, he shall be
My tutor by his wit and pollicie. Exit.

STAGE.HI: Enter Boy in a Shop cutting of square parchments, to him enter Phillis.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Why how now sirra, can you finde nought to doe,
But waste the parchment in this idle sort?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy
SP.L: I do but what my mistris gaue in charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Your mistris! in good time: then sir it seemes
Your duety cannot stoope but to her lewre:
Sir, I will make you knowe, that in hir absence
You shall accompt to my demaund, your mistris
And your mistris will is thus, and thus youle doe:
But answere to the motion I haue made,
Or you shall feele you haue another mistris now:
Speake, why when I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy
SP.L: Indeede I know your glory.
Your pride's at full in this authoritie:
But, were it not for modest bashfulnesse,
And that I dread a base contentious name,
I would not be a by-word to th'Exchange,
For euery one to say (my selfe going by)
Yon goes a vassal to authoritie.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: You would not sir: had I the yeard in hand,
Ide measure your pate for this delusion,
And by my maiden chastitie I sweare,
Vnlesse Reach for the yeard, and the boy stay her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy
SP.L: What vnlesse! I know your wilfulnes,
These wordes are but to shew the world your humour.
I often vse to square these parchment peeces
Without occasion: I am sure you are not witting
The Lawnes you lately bought of maister Brookes
Are new come home, brought by the Merchants seruant:
I know you are short membred, but not so short
Of your remembrance, that this is newes to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Y'are best to braue me in a taunting humour.
Wilt please you ope the doore? wheres Vrsula?
Oh heeres good stuffe, my backe's no sooner turnd
But she must needes be gadding, and where I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Shee's gone to M. Pawmers on th'other side.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: On great occasions, sir, I doubt it not.

DIV1.STAGE: Sit and worke in the shop.
Enter M. Richard Gardiner booted, and M. William Bennet, two gentlemen, at one ende of the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.L: Kinde Dicke, thou wilt not be vnmindfull of my dutie
To that same worthy Arts-master, Lyonell Barnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: Thy loue, sweet Will, hath chainde it to my memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.L: Then with this kinde imbrace I take my leaue,
Wishing thou wert as safe arriu'd at Cambridge,
As thou art at this present neere the Exchange.

SP.SPEAKER: Gard
SP.L: And well remembred, kind Will Bennet,
Others affaires made me obliuious
Of mine owne; I pray thee goe to the Exchange,
I haue certaine bands, and other linnen to buy,
Prethee accompanie me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.L: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: Sure, this is a beauteous gallant walke.
Were my continuall residence in London,
I should make much vse of such a pleasure:
Me thinkes the glorious virgins of this square
Giues life to dead strucke youth; Oh heauens!

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.L: Why how now Dicke?

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: By my sweete hopes of an hereafter blisse,
I neuer saw a fairer face then this:
O for acquaintance with so rich a beautie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.L: Take thy occasion, neuer hadst thou better.

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: Haue at her then.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: What lacke you Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: Faith nothing, had I thee.
For in thine eye all my desires I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: My shop you meane sir, there you may haue choice
Of Lawnes, or Cambricks, Ruffes well wrought, Shirts,
Fine falling bands of the Italian cut-worke,
Ruffes for your hands, wast-cotes wrought with silke,
Night-caps of gold, or such like wearing linnen,
Fit for the Chap-man of what ere degree.

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: Faith virgin in my dayes, I haue worne & out-worne much,
Yea, many of these golden necessaries;
But such a gallant beautie, or such a forme
I neuer saw, nor neuer wore the like:
Faith be not then vnkinde, but let me weare
This shape of thine, although I buy it deere.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: What hath the Tailor plaide his part so well,
That with my gowne you are so farre in loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: Mistake not sweet your garment is the couer,
That vailes the shape and pleasures of a louer.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: That argues then, you doe not see my shape,
How comes it then you are in loue with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: A garment made by cunning Arts-mens skill,
Hides all defects that Natures swaruing hand
Hath done amisse, and makes the shape seeme pure;
If then it grace such lame deformitie,
It addes a greater grnce to puritie.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Oh short liu'd praise! euen now I was as faire
As any thing; now fouler nothing.
Dissembling men, what maide will credite them?

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: How misconstruction leades your thoughts awry.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.L: I prethee Dicke adone; thinke on thy iourney.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: You counsell well sir, I thinke the Gentleman
Comes but to whet his wit, and tis but need;
Tis blunt enough, he may ride farre vpon't.

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: Mary gip Minx.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: A fine word in a Gentlemans mouth;
T'were good your backe were towards me,
There can I reade better content, then in the face of lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: Now you display your vertues, as they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: What am I, you, Cipher, parrenthesis of words,
Stall-troubler, prater, what sit I heere for naught?
Bestow your lustfull court-ships on your minions,
This place holds none; you and your companion
Get you downe the staires, or I protest
Ile make this squared walke too botte for you.
Had you been as you seemd in out-ward shew,
Honest Gentlemen, such termes of vilde abuse
Had not been proffred to virginitie;
But Swaines will quickly shew their base desent.

SP.SPEAKER: Gard.
SP.L: This is no place for brawles, but if it were,
Your impositions are more then I would beare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.L: Come, shee's a woman, I prethee leaue her.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Nay sure a maid, vnlesse her thoughts deceiue her.
God speede you well: sirra boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Anone.
Got to the Starchers for the sute of ruffes,
For M. Bowdlers bands, and M. Goldings shirts,
Lets haue a care to please our prooued friends:
As for our strangers, if they vse vs well,
For loue and money, loue and ware weele sell. Exeunt

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Franke. The Cripple at worke.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Now fortune be my guide, this is the shop;
And in good time the Cripple is at worke:
God speede you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Welcome honest friend; whats thy will with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I would entreat you reade a letter for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: With all my heart:
I know the maide to whom it is directed.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I know you doe Cripple, better then you thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: I pray you, what Gentleman writ the same?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Sir, a Gentleman of good learning, and my friend;
To say the truth, t'was written for my selfe,
Being some-what ouertaken with fond loue,
As many men be sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Why art thou perswaded, or haste thou any hope,
So beautifull a virgin as she is,
Of such faire parentage; so vertuous,
So gentle, kinde, and wise as Phillis is,
That she will take remorse of such base stuffe,
I thinke not so: but let me see, whats thy name?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Trustie Iohn men call me sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: How comes it then your blinded Secretarie,
Hath writ another name vnto the letter?
Yours deuoted Anthony Golding.
But sure this letter is no right of thine,
Either thou foundst the same by happy chance,
Or being imployed as a Messenger,
Plaid'st leger dumaine with him that sent the same:
Wherefore the maid (well knowne vnto my selfe)
I will reserue the letter to her vse,
That she, if by the name herein set downe,
She know the Gentleman that doth wish her well,
She may be gratefull for his courtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Nay then I see I must disclose my selfe:
Sir, might I build vpon your secrecie,
I would disclose a secret of import.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Assure thy selfe I will not iniure thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.L: Then Cripple know, I am not what I seem,
But tooke this habite to deceiue my friend:
My friend indeed, but yet my cruell foe;
Foe to my good, my friend in outward show:
I am no Porter, as I seeme to bee,
But yonger brother to that Anthony;
And to be briefe, I am in loue with Phillis,
Which my two elder brothers do affect:
The one of them seekes to defeat the other:
Now if that I, being their yonger brother
Could gull them both, by getting of the wench,
I would requite it with loues recompence.
Cripple, thou once didst promise me thy loue,
When I did rescue thee on Mile-end Greene,
Now is the time, now let me haue thy ayd,
To gull my brothers of that beauteous mayd.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Sir, what I promisde I will now performe;
My loue is yours, my life to doe you good,
Which to approoue, follow me but in all,
Weele gull your brothers in the wench, and all.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Saist thou me so friend, for that very word
My life is thine, command my hand and sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Then let me see this letter; it should see me
You vnder-tooke to carry from your brother
To the maide.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: I did, and from my brother Ferdinand,
This other letter to the same effect.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Well, list to me, and follow my aduise,
You shall deliuer neither of them both;
But frame two letters of your owne inuention,
Letters of flat deniall to their sutes,
Giue them to both your brothers as from Phillis,
And let each line in either Letter tend
To the dispraise of both their features;
And the conclusion I would haue set downe,
A flat resolue bound with some zealous oath,
Neuer to yeeld to eyther of their sutes:
And if this sort not well to your content,
Condemne the Cripple.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: But this will aske much time,
And they by this time looke for my returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Why then my selfe will fit you presently,
I haue the Coppies in my custody,
Of sundry Letters to the same effect.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Of thy owne writing?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: My owne I assure you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Faith thou hast robd some Sonet booke or other,
And now wouldst make me thinke they are thine owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Why, thinkst thou that I cannot write a letter,
Ditty, or Sonnet with iudiciall phrase,
As pretty, pleasing, and patheticall,
As the best Ouid-immitating dance
In all the towne.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: I thinke thou canst not.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Yea, ile sweare I cannot,
Yet sirra, I could conny-catch the world,
Make my selfe famous for a sodaine wit,
And be admirde for my dexteritie,
Were I disposde.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: I pre thee how.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Why thus there liu'd a Poet in this towne,
(If we may terme our moderne Writers Poets)
Sharpe-witted, bitter-tongd, his penne of steele,
His incke was temperd with the biting iuyce,
And extracts of the bitterst weedes that grew,
He neuer wrote but when the elements
Of Fire and Water tilted in his braine:
This fellow ready to giue vp his ghost
To Luciaes bosome, did bequeathe to me
His Library, which was iust nothing,
But rolles, and scrolles, and bundles of cast wit,
Such as durst neuer visit Paules churchyard:
Amongst them all, I happened on a quire
Or two of paper filld with Songs and Ditties,
And heere and there a hungry Epigramme,
These I reserue to my owne proper vse,
And Pater-noster-like haue kon'd them all.
I could now when I am in company,
At ale house, tauerne, or an ordinarie,
Vpon a theame make an extemporall ditty,
(Or one at least should seeme extemporall)
Out of th'aboundance of this Legacie,
That all would judge it, and report it too,
To be the infant of a sodaine wit,
And then were I an admirahle fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: This were a peece of cunning.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: I could doe more, for I could make enquirie
Where the best witted Gallants vse to dine,
Follow them to the tauerne, and there sit
In the next rowme with a calues head and brimstone,
And ouer heare their talke, obserue their humours,
Collect their jeasts, put them into a play,
And tire them too with payment to behold
What I haue filcht from them. This I could doe:
But O for shame that men should so arraigne
Their owne fee simple wits, for verball theft!
Yet men there be that haue done this and that,
And more by much more than the most of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: But to our purpose Cripple to these letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Cripple
SP.L: I haue them ready for you, heere they be,
Giue these to your two brothers, say that Phillis
Deliuered them with frownes, and though her name
Be not subscribde (which may not well be done)
It may perhaps giue them occasion
To thinke she scornd them so much grace and fauour.
This done, returne to me, and let me know
Th'occurrants of this prastise as they growe,
And so farewell, I can no longer stand
To talke with you, I haue some worke in hand. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Farewell mad Cripple, now Franke Golaing slie,
To put in practise this new pollicie:
But soft, heere comes the Maide, I wil assay
To pleade my owne loue by a stranger way,
By your leaue sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Porter, I am not for you, you see I am perambulating before a female.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.P: I would craue but a word with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Speake in time then Porter, for otherwise I doe not loue to answer you, and bee as briefe as you can, good Por∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I pray you sir, what Gentlewoman is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle.
SP.P: Certes Porter, I serue a Gentleman, that Gentle∣man is father to this Gentlewoman, this Gentlewoman is a maide, this maide is faire, and this faire maide belongeth to the Exchange, and the Exchange hath not the like faire maid now Porter, put al this together, and tel me what it spels.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.P: I promise you sir, you haue posde me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Then you are an asse Porter, tis the faire Maide of the Exchange.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Hir name I pray you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle.
SP.P: Her name Porter requires much poeticalitie in the subscription, and no lesse iudgement in the vnderstanding; her name is Phillis, not Phillis that same dainty lasse that was beloued of Amintas, nor Phillis shee that doated on that comely youth Demophoon, but this is Phillis, that most strange Phillis, the flowre of the Exchange.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: What, would that Porter any thing with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Yes Mistris, since by chaunce I meete you heere,
Ile tell you, though it not concernes my selfe,
What I this morning sawe; there is a Gentleman
One master Golding the yongest of three brothers,
They call him Franke; O this man lies very sicke,
I being at his house perchance enquired
What his disease was of a seruant there,
Who said, the doctors cannot tell themselues,
But in his fittes he euer calles on Loue,
And prayes to Loue for pitty, and then names you,
And then names Loue againe, and then calles Phillis,
And sometime startes, and would forsake his bed,
And being askt whither, he sayes he would goe to Phillis,
My busines calld me hence, but I heard say
His friends doe meane to intreate you to take the paines
To visit him, because they do suppose,
The sicke man loues you, and thence his sickenes growes.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Porter, is this true?
Or art thou hired to this, I prethee tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Mistris, not hired, my name is Trusty Iohn.
If I delude you, neuer trust me more.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: I thanke thee Porter, and thanke Loue withall,
That thus hath wrought the tyrant Goldings fall,
He once scornd Loue, jeasted at wounded hearts,
Challengde almighty beauty, raild at passion,
And is he now caught by the eies and heart?
Now by Dianaes milke white vaile I sweare,
The goddesse of my maiden chaste desires.
I am as glad of it as glad may be,
And I will see him, if but to laugh at him,
And torture him with jeasts; Fiddle, along,
When we returne, if they doe send for me,
Ile arme my selfe with flowts and crueltie.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.L: Porter, wee committe you, if you be a crafty knaue, and lay in the winde for a vantage, you haue your answere: marke her last wordes, ile arme my selfe with flowtes and cruelty. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Ile arme my selfe with floutes and crueltie.
Will you so Phillis, what a state am I in?
Why I of all am furthest from her loue:
Sblood, if I now should take conceit at this,
Fall sicke with loue indeed, were not my state
Most lamentable? I by this hand were it:
Well heart, if thou wilt yeeld, looke to thy selfe,
Thou wilt be tortur'd, well what remedie.
Here comes my brother Anthonie, I am for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Porter, what newes? spake you with Phillis?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I too late, to my griefe,
Spoke with her, sir, Yfaith I thinke I haue;
Heer's a letter for you, and by that
You shall be iudge if I did speake with her;
Now Cripple, shall we prooue your learned wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Zounds am I mad, or is she mad that writ this?
Ile reade it or'e againe:

LETTER.HEAD: A Letter.
LETTER.P: SIr, I did neuer like you, I doe not nowe thinke well of you, And I will neuer loue you: I choose my husband with my eyes, and I haue seene some especiall fault in you; as the co∣lour of your haire, the eleuating of your head, to an affected proportion, as if you fainted for want of aire, and stood in that manner to sucke it into your nose, your neck is too long: and to be short, I like no part in or about you: and the short and the long boy, is, that I will neuer loue you, and I will ne∣uer marry but one I loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.L: Blancke, I am strucke blancke, and blind, and mad withall,
Heere is a flat denyall to my sute,
A resolution neuer to be wonne:
What shall I doe? assist me God of loue,
Instruct me in thy schoole-tricks; be my guide
Out of this laborinth of loue and feare,
Vnto the pallace of faire Phillis fauour:
I haue it; I will intimate her mother
In my behalfe, with letters and with gifts,
To her ile write to be my aduocate:
Porter farewell, ther's for thy paines,
Thy profite by this toyle passeth my gaines. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: You haue your answer, and a kind one too;
Cripple ile make thee chrutches of pure siluer
For this deuise, thou hast a golden wit;
Now if my brother Ferdinand were heere
To reade his absolution, heere he comes.
Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Franke.
What hast thou giuen the letter to her hand,
And staid my brother Anthonies withall?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.L: I haue done both, and more then that, behold
Heere is an answere to your letter brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Franke, I will loue thee, whiles I liue for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke.
SP.L: Scarce, when you reade what there contained is.

LETTER.HEAD: A Letter.
LETTER.P: GAllant, that write for loue, if you had come your self yon might perchance haue sped; I do not counsell you nei∣ther, to come your selfe, vnlesse you leaue your head at home, or weare a vizard, or come backe-wardes, for I neuer looke you in the face but I am sicke: and so praying God to conti∣nue my health, by keeping you from me, I leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: O vnkinde answere to a Louers letter;
Let me suruay the end once more: For I neuer looke you in the face but I am sicke: and so prai∣ing God to continue me in health, by keeping you from mee.
Is shee so farre from yeelding? is this fort
Of her chaste loue yet so impregnable?
What shall I doe? this is the furthest way,
A labour of impossibilities:
This way to winne her? I will once againe,
Challenge the promise that her father made me;
To him ile write, and he I know will pleade
My loue to Phillis, and so winne the maide. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Farewell poore tortur'd heart; was euer knowne
Two louing brothers in such miserie?
Let me consider of my owne estate:
What profit do I reape by this delusion?
Why none; I am as farre from Phillis heart
As when she first did wound me with her eyes:
Cripple, to thee I come, tis thou must be
My counsellor in this extreamitie. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: Sirra Bowdler, what makes thee in this merry vaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.P: O Lord sir, it is your most eleuated humor to be mer∣ry, to be concise, set vp the coller, and looke thus with a dou∣ble chinne, like Diogenes peering ouer his Tub, is too cymi∣call, the signe of Melancholly, and indeede, the meere effect of a salt rhume.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: Who would thinke this Gentleman yesterdayes dis∣temperature should breed such motions? I thinke it be resto∣ratiue to actiuitie, I neuer saw a gentleman caper so excellent, as he did last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Meane you me sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Your owne selfe, by this hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: You gull me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: How, gull you!
Me thinkes a man so well reputed of,
So well commended for your quallities
In Schooles of nimble actiuenesse,
And places where diuinest Querristers
Warble inchanting harmonie, to such
As thinke there is no heauen on earth but theirs:
And knowing your selfe to be the Genius
Of the spectators, and the audience hearts,
You wrong your worthy selfe intollerably,
To thinke our words sauor of flatterie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Sirra dogge, how didst thou like my last caper, and turne a the toe?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Before God passing well.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: I know his worship made it, tis so excellent,

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: It was my yesterdayes exercise.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: After the working of your purgation, was it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: What purgation, you filthy curre?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: After the purging of your braine Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Be still dogge, barke not, though by mis-fortune
I was last night somewhat distempered:
I will not be vpbraided; t'was no more
But to refine my wit; but tell me truely,
How dost thou like my caper?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Farre better than I can commend it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Now as I am a Gentleman
My Tutor was not witting of the same;
And in my opinion t'will doe excellent:
O this aire! heer's a most eloquious aire for the memorie,
I could spend the third part of my Armes in siluer,
To be encountred by some good wit or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: What say you to your sweet heart, Mall Berry?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
