SP.P: Peace Cripple, silence, name her not, I could not indure the carrire of her wit, for a million, shee is the onely shee Mercury vnder the heauens; her wit is all spirit; that spirit fire, that fire flies from her tongue, able to burne the radix of the best inuention; in this Element shee is the abstract and breefe of all the eloquence since the incarnation of Tullies I tell thee Cripple, I had rather incounter Hercules with blowes, than Mall Berry with words: And yet by this light I am horribly in loue with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: See where she comes, O excellent!

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Now haue I no more blood than a bull-rush.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: How now; what aile you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Whats the matter man?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: See, see, that glorious angell doth approach,
What shall I doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Shee is a saint indeed; Zounds to her, court her, win her, weare her, wed her, and bed her too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: I would it were come to that, I win her! by heauen, I am not furnish'd of a courting phrase, to throw at a dogge.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L:
Why no, but at a woman you haue; O sir, seeme not so doultish now, can you make nofustian, aske her if sheele
take a pipe of Tobacco.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: It wil offend her iudgement, pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cri.
SP.L: But heare you sir? reading so much as you haue done,
Doe you not remember one pretty phrase,
To scale the walles of a faire wenches loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: I neuer read any thing but Venus and Adonis.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Why thats the very quintessence of loue,
If you remember but a verse or two,
Ile pawne my head, goods, lands and all twill doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Why then haue at her.
Fondling I say, since I haue hemd thee heere,
Within the circle of this iuory pale,
Ile be a parke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Hands off fond sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: And thou shalt be my deere;
Feede thou on me, and I will feede on thee,
And Loue shall feede vs both.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Feede you on woodcockes, I can fast awhile.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Vouchsafe thou wonder to alight thy steede.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Take heede, shees not on horsebacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Why then she is alighted,
Come sit thee downe where neuer serpent hisses,
And being set, ile smother thee with kisses.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Why is your breath so hot? now God forbid
I should buy kisses to be smotherd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: Meane you me? you gull me not?

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: No, no, poore Bowdler, thou dost gull thy selfe:
Thus must I do to shadow the hid fire,
That in my heart doth burne with hot desire:
O I doe loue him well what ere I say,
Yer will I not my selfe selfe loue bewray,
If he be wise hee'l sue with good take heede:
Bowdler, doe so, and thou art sure to speede:
I will flie hence to make his loue the stronger,
Though my affection must lie hid the longer.
What maister Bowdler, not a word to say?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: No by my troth, if you stay heere all day.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Why then ile beare the bucklers hence away. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: What maister Bowdler, haue you let her passe vncon∣querd?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Why what could I doe more? I lookt vpon her with iudgement, the strings of my tongue were well in tune, my embraces were in good measure, my palme of a good consti∣tution, onely the phrase was not moouing; as for example, Venus her selfe with all her skill could not winne Adonis, with the same wordes: O heauens! was I so fond then to thinke that I could conquer Mall Berry? O the naturall fluence of my owne wit had beene farre better!
SP.L: Godden good fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: God giue you the time of the day, pardon mee Gal∣lants, I was so neere the middle that I knew not which hand to take.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: A very good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: And yet because I wil be sure to giue you a true salu∣tation, Cripple, quomodo vales? Good morrow Cripple, good∣den good maister Barnard, maister Bowdler, Bonos noches, as they say, good night; and thus you haue heard my manner of salutation.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: You are very eloquent, sir; but Fiddle, whats the best newes abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: The best newes I know not sir, but the newest news is most excellent yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.P: Prethee lets heare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Why this it is, the Serieants are watching to arrest you at maister Berries sute.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.P: Wounds, where?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Nay, I know not where; alas sir, there is no such mat∣ter, I did but say so much, to make you warme the handle of your rapier: But M. Bawdler, I haue good newes for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Let me heare it, my sweete russetting.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: How, russeting?

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: I my little apple Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: You are a

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: A what?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: You are a, O that I could speake for indignation!

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Nay, what am I?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Yon are a pippinmonger to call me Russetting or ap∣ple Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Sirra Russetting, ile pare your head off.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: You pippinmonger, Ile cut off your legs, and make you trauel so neere the mother earth, that euery boy shall be high enough to steale apples out of thy basket, call mee Rus∣setting?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: Nay, be friends, be friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: As I am a gentleman cripple, I meant him no harme, but the name of Russetting to maister Fiddle, that many times trauells vnder the arme in veluet, but for the most part in lea∣ther trussd with calue-skinne points, tis most tolerable, and not to be indured, flesh and bloud cannot beare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: Come, come, all shall be well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Fiddle, giue me thy hand, a plague on thee, thou kno∣west I loue thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: Say you so? why then anger auoid the roume, melan∣choly march away, choler to the next chamber, and heres my hand I am yours to command from this time foorth, your ve∣ry mortall frend, and louing enemy, maister Fiddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.P: Now tell vs, what is the newes you had for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.P: O, the sweet newes, faith sir, this it is, that I was sent to the Cripple from my young Mistris. Maister Cripple you know I haue spent some time in idle words, therefore be you compendions, and tell me if my mistris handkercher be done or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Cri.
SP.P: Fiddle tis done, & peace it is, cōmend me to thy mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Fidd.
SP.P: After the most humble maner I will; and so gentle∣men I commit you all: you Cripple to your shop; you sir, to a turn-vp and dish of capers; and lastly, you M. Barnard, to the tuition of the Counter-keeper: theres an Item for you, and so fare-well. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: M. Bowdler, how do you like his humour?

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.P: By this light, I had not thought the clod had had so nimble a spirit: but Cripple farewell, Ile to Mall Berry, come Barnard along with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.P: Farewel sweet Signiors both, farewel, farewel. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter M. Flower at one doore reading a letter from Ferdinand, at the other Mistris Flower, with a Letter from Anthonie.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.P: The conceit is good, Ferdinand intreats a mar∣riage with my daughter; good, very good: for he is a Gentle∣man of good carriage, a wise man, a rich man, a carefull man, and therefore worthy of my daughters loue: it shall be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.P: Mary and shall, kind Gentleman, my furthe∣rance saist thou? Yes Anthony, assure thy selfe, for by the mo∣therly care that I beare to my daughter, it hath been a desire that long hath lodgde within my carefull breast, to match hir with thy well-deseruing selfe; and to this end haue I sent for my daughter, and chargde my seruants, that presently vp∣on her repaire hither from her Mistrisses, that shee enter this priuate walke, where, and with whome, I will so worke, that doubt it not, deere sonne, but she shall be thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Master Flo.
SP.P: And I will make her ioyncture of a hundred pounds by yeare: it is a very good conceit, and why? bicause the worthy portion betters my conceit, which being good in conceiuing well of the Gentlemans good partes, the proffe∣red ioyncture addes to my conceit, and betters it, very good.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.P: A thousand crowns for you to make the match, pretty heart, how loue can worke! by Gods blest mother, I vow she shall be thine, if I haue any interest in my daughter; Flower smiles reading the Letter, they snatch the Letter from each other. but stay, whom haue I espied? my husband likewise reading of a Letter, and in so good an humour, ile lay my life, good Gentleman hee hath also wrought with him for his good wil; and for I long to know the truth thereof, my sodaine purpose shall experience it. Whats heere husband? She reades priuately, and frownes. a Letter from maister Ferdinand, to intreate a marriage with your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.P: And here the like to you from Anthony to that effect, this is no good conceit, if shee be mine, shee shall be Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: If shee respect her mothers fauour,
Tis Anthony shall be her loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: How wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Euen so husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: You will not crosse my purpose, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: In this you shall not bridle me I sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Is she not my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: You teach me husband, what your wife should say,
I thinke her life is deerest vnto me,
Though you forget the long extreamitie
And paine which I indurd, when foorth this wombe
With much adoe she did inioy the life she now doth breathe,
And shall I now suffer her destruction?

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Yea but conceit me wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: A figge for your conceits, in this I know there can be none that:
Say he be his fathers eldest sonne, and a merchaunt of good wealth, yet my deere Anthonies as rich as he:
What though his portion was but small at first,
His industrie hath now increasd his talent;
And he that knoweth the getting of a penny,
Will feare to spend, she shall haue him, if any.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: By the Mary God wife, you vex me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Tis your owne impatience, you may chuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: I will not wed my daughter to that Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: By this.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Hold wife, hold, I aduise thee sweare not,
For by him that made me, first I vow,
She shall not touch the bed of Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: And may I neuer liue (so God me help)
If euer she be wed to Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: The diuel's in this woman, how she thwartes me still!

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Fret on, good husband, I will haue my will.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: But conceit me wife, suppose we should con∣sent our daughter should wedde either of them both, and shee dislike the match, were that a good conceit?

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: All's one for that, I know my daughters mind if I but say the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: I would be loath to wed her against hir will,
Content thee wife, weele heare her resolution,
And as I finde her, to her owne content
To either of them she shall haue my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Why now old Flower speaketh like himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Agreed, and faith wife tis a good conceit,
And see where my daughter comes: welcome gerle,
How doth your Mistris Phillis? God blesse thee Phillis, rise.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: God haue the glory, in perfect health she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Tis good, I am glad she doth so well;
But list my daughter, I haue golden newes
To impart vnto thee:
A golden, Golding, wench, must be thy husband,
Is't not a good conceit?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Father, I vnderstand you not.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Then, my gerle, thy conceit is very shallow,
Maister Ferdinand Golding is in loue with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: No daughter, tis thine Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Ferdinand is rich, for he hath store of gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Anthony is rich, yet is not so old.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Ferdinand is vertuous, full of modestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Anthony's more gratious, if more may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Ferdinand is wise (being wise) who would not loue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Anthony more wise, then Gerle desire to proue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: In Ferdinand is all the beauty that may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: He is deceiu'd, tis in thine Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Deare Parents, you confound me with your wordes,
I pray what meane these hote perswasions?

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Thy good my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: If but rulde by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: But for thy ill-fare.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: If she tend to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: The trueth is this, that each of vs hath tane
A solemne vow, that thou my louing daughter
Shalt wed with one of those two gentlemen:
But yet referre the choice vnto thy selfe,
One thou shalt loue, loue Ferdinand, if me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistresse Flo.
SP.L: If loue thy mother, loue thine Anthonie.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: In these extreames what shall become of me?
I pray you giue me respite to consider
How to disgest these impositions,
You haue imposde a busines of such weight,
Pray God your daughter may discharge her selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Thinke on't, my gerle, we will withdrawe a∣while.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: A little respite fits my resolution, They walke.
Those Gentles sue too late, there is another,
Of better worth, though not of halfe their wealth,
What though deform'd, his vertue mends that misse;
What though not rich, his wit doth better gold,
And my estate shall adde vnto his wants,
I am resolu'd (good father, and deere mother,)
Phillis doth choose a Cripple, and none other;
But yet I must dissemble.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: How now my soules best hope! tell mee, my gerle,
Shall Ferdinand be he?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: I pray a word in priuate.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Mary with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: In all the duety that a childe can shew,
The loue that to a father it doth owe;
I yeeld my selfe to be at your commaund,
And vow to wed no man but Ferdinand.
But if you please, at your departure hence,
You may inforce dislike to cloude your brow,
To avoyde my mothers anger and suspition.

SP.SPEAKER: M Flo.
SP.L: Before God a very good conceit,
Hence baggage, out of my sight,
Come not within my doores, thou hadst been better,
Runne millions of miles bare footed, then
Thus by your coy disdaine to haue deluded me.
Oh mine owne flesh and blood, the mirror of wit!
Now will I hence, and with all the speed I may
Send for my sonne, ile haue it done this day. Exit old Flow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistresse Flow.
SP.L: What, is he gone? and in so hot a chafe?
Well let him goe, I need not question why,
For well I wote his sute is cold, t'must die.
Daughter, I gather by thy pleasant smiles,
Thy mother hath more interest in thy loue,
Than discontented Flower thy aged father.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Mother, you haue, for when I well consider
A mothers care vnto her deere bought childe,
How tenderly you nurcde and brought me vp,
I could not be so much vnnaturall
As to refuse the loue you proffer me,
Especially being for my chiefest good;
Therefore when married I intend to be,
My loyall husband shall be Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Fl.
SP.L: Liue euer then my deere deere daughter Phillis,
Let me imbrace thee in a mothers armes;
Thus, thus and thus ile euer hugge my daughter,
Him hence thou sendst with frowns, me hence with laughter,
Come Phillis, let vs in.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Forsooth ile follow you.
Am not I a good childe thinke you,
To play with both hands thus against my parents?
Well, tis but a tricke of youth: say what they will,
Ile loue the Cripple, and will hate them still. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Cripple in his shop, and to him enters Franke.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Mirrour of kindnesse, extremities best friend,
While I breathe, sweete bloud, I am thine,
Intreate me, nay commaund thy Frances heart,
That wilt not suffer my insuing smart.

SP.SPEAKER: Cripp.
SP.L: Sweet signior, my aduise in the reseruation of those Letters,
Which I will haue you hide from eie of day,
Neuer to feele the warmth of Phoebus beames,
Till my selfes care, most carefull of your weale,
Summon those lines vnto the barre of Ioy.

SP.SPEAKER: Francke
SP.L: I will not erre, deere friend, in this commaund.

SP.SPEAKER: Cripple
SP.L: So much for that, now listen further Francke,
Not yet two houres expiration,
Haue taken finall end, since Beauties pride,
And Natures better part of workemanship,
Beauteous Phillis was with me consorted;
Where she mongst other pleasing conference,
Burst into termes of sweet affection,
And said, ere long she would conuerse with me
In priuate at my shop, whose wounded soule
Strucke with loues golden arrow liues in dread,
Till she doe heare the sentence of my loue,
Or be condemn'd by iudgement of fell hate.
Now since that gracious opportunitie
Thus smiles on me, I will resigne the same
To you my friend, knowing my vnworthy selfe
Too foule for such a beautie, and too base
To match in brightnesse with that sacred comet.
That shines like Phaebus in Londons Element;
From whence inferior starres deriue their light:
Wherefore I will immediatly you take
My crooked habite, and in that disguise
Court her, yea win her, for she will be wonne,
This will I doe, to pleasure you my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: For which my loue to thee shall neuer end.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: About it then, assume this shape of mine,
Take what I haue. for all I haue is thine?
Supply my place, to gaine thy hearts desire,
So may you quench too hearts that burne like fire:
Shee's kind to mee, be she as kinde to you,
What admiration will there then insue?
Franke, I will leaue thee, now be thou fortunate,
That we with ioy your loues may consummate,
Farewell, farewell, when I returne againe,
I hope to finde thre in a pleasing vaine. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Farewell deere friend; was euer known a finer policie?
Now brothers, haue amongst you for a third part,
Nay, for the whole, or by my soule, ile loose all,
What though my father did bequeath his lands
To you my elder brethren, the moueables I sue for
Were none of his: and you shall runne through fire,
Before you touch one part of my desire:
Am I not like my selfe in this disguise,
Crooked in shape, and crooked in my thoughts
Then am I a Cripple right, come wench, away,
Thy absence breeds a terror to my stay.
Yonder she comes, now frame thy hands to draw,
A worser workeman neuer any saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Yea yonder sits the wonder of mine eye;
I haue not been the first whom destenie
Hath thwarted thus; imperious Loue,
Either withdraw the shaft that wounds my heart,
Or grant me patience to indure my smart:
Remorcelesse loue, had any but thy selfe
Beene priuie to my direfull passion,
How I consume and waste my selfe in loue,
They would haue beene, yea much more pittifull:
But all auailes not; demaunding for my worke
Shall be a meanes to haue some conference.
Good morrow to you, is my handkercher done?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Yea Mistresse Flower, it is finished.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: How sweetly tunes the accent of his voyce!
Oh, do not blame me, deerest loue aliue,
Though thus I dote in my affection;
I toyle, I labor, and I faine would thriue,
And thriue I may if thou wouldst giue direction:
Thou art the starre whereby my course is led,
Be gracious then, bright sunne, or I am dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Faire Mistresse Phillis, such wanton toyes as these,
Are for yong Nouices that will soone bee pleasde,
The carefull thoughts that hammer in my braine,
Bid me abandon wanton loue; tis vaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: For me it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Is my vngarnishd, darke, and obscure Cell,
A mansion fit for all-commanding loue?
No, if thou wilt sport with loue,
And dally with that wanton amorous boy;
Hie thee vnto the odoriferous groues.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: There is no groues more pleasant vnto me,
Then to be still in thy societie.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke.
SP.L: There of the choisest fragrant flowers that grow
Thou maist deuise sweete roseat Corronets,
And with the Nimphs that haunt the siluer streames,
Learne to entice the affable yong wagge;
There shalt thou finde him wand ring vp and downe,
Till some faire saint impale him with a crowne:
Be gone I say, and doe not trouble mee,
For to be short, I cannot fancy thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: For to be short, you cannot fancie me:
Oh cruell word, more hatefull then pale death,
Oh, would to God it would conclude my breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Forbeare, forbeare, admit that I should yeild:
Thinke you, your father would applaud your choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Doubt not thereof, or if he do not, alls one,
So you but grant to my affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: I am too base.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: My wealth shall raise thee vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: I am deform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Tut, I will beare with that.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Your friends dislike brings all this out of frame.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: By humble sute I will redresse the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Now to employ the vertue of my shape:
Faire mistresse,
If heretofore I haue remorselesse beene,
And not esteemd your vndeserued loue,
Whereby in the glasse of your affection
I see my great vnkindnesse; forgine what's past,
And here I proffer all the humble seruice
Your hie prizde loue doth merrit at my hands,
Which I confesse is more then I vnable
Can gratefie: therefore command my toyle,
My trauell, yea, my life to pleasure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: I take thee at thy word, prowd of thy seruice,
But yet no seruant shalt thou be of mine,
I will serue thee, command, and ile obey:
This doth my soule more good, yea, ten times more
Then did thy harsh deniall harme before,
Let vs imbrace like two vnited friends,
Heere loue begins, and former hatred ends.

STAGE.HI: Enter Ferdinand and Anthonie walking together.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Brother Anthony, what newes from Venice?
Are your ships return'd? I had rather aside.
Heare newes from Phillis: Oh, brother Franke,
Thy absence makes me burne in passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Sir, I had letters from my factors there
Some three dayes since; but the returne of one, aside.
Of one poore letter, yet not answered,
Makes me starke madde: a plague vpon that Porter,
Damn'd may he be for thus deluding me.
SP.STAGE: Ferdinand spies Phillis and turnes backe.
SP.L: How now brother, why retire you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Yonders a friend of mine acquaintance,
With whom I would gladly haue some conference,
I pray thee stay I will returne immediatly.

DIV1.STAGE: Goe to Phillis and court her to themselues.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Of your acquaintance; is she so good brother?
Onely with you acquainted, and no other?
Faith ile trie that, take heed sir what you doe.
If you begin to court, I needs must woe, Go to her too.
Brother haue you done?

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: But two words more at most:
You haue not then receiu'd any such letter?
A vengeance take the lazie messenger;
Brother if I liue, ile quittance thee for this,

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Good words, deere brother, threatned men liue long.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: You haue done.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Then by your leaue brother,
You had one word, I must haue another. Talke in priuate.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I know our businesse tends to one effect:
O that villaine Franke, it mads my soule
I am so wrong'd, by such a foolish Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: That foolish boy may chance prooue to be witty:
What, and the elder brothers fooles? Oh ti's pittie!

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: That villaiue Porter hath deluded me,
Confusion guerdon his base villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: What are you cursing too? then we catch no fish:
Comes there any more, heeres two Snights to a dish.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Well, since I haue such opportunitie,
Ile trust no longer to vncertaintie.

DIV1.STAGE: He courts her againe in priuate.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: At it so hard brother; well, woe apace,
A while I am content to giue you place.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Well, to her both, both doe the best you can;
I feare yong Franke will prooue the happier man.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: You haue your answere, trouble me no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Fer.
SP.L: Yet this is worse then my suspence before,
For then I liu'd in hope, now hope is fled.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: What, male content? is Ferdinand strooke dead,
Fortune be blithe, and aide the second brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke.
SP.L: Thinke you to haue more fauour then an other?
To her a Gods name, liue not in suspence,
While you two striue, I needs must get the wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: I am resolu'd, and, sir you know my minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: What, you repulst too? Phillis is too vnkinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Here sits my Loue, within whose louely brest
Liues my content, and all my pleasures rest,
And for a further confirmation,
Which to approoue, euen in sight of both you here present,
I giue my hand, and with my hand, my heart,
My selfe, and all to him; and with this ring
Ile wed my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I take thy offering,
And for the gift you gaue to me, take this,
And let vs seale affection with a kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Oh sight intollerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: A spectacle worse then death.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Now gentlemen, please you draw neere and listen to the Cripple.
SP.STAGE: Giue them the letters and they stampe and storme.
SP.L: Know you that letter? sir, what say you to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: How came they to your hands?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank
SP.L: Sirs, a porter euen of late left them with me,
To be deliuered to this Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: A plague vpon that Porter; if ere I meete him,
My rapiers point with a deaths wound shall greet him. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Franke thou art a villaine, thou shalt know't ere long.
For proffering me such vndeserued wrong. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: So, vomit forth the rhume of all your spight,
These threats of yours procure me more delight.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Now gentle loue, all that I haue to say,
Is to entreat you seeke without delay,
My fathers kinde consent, for thou hast mine,
And though he storme yet will I still be thine;
Make triall then, tis but thy labour lost,
Though he denie thee, it requires no cost.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I will assaile with expedition.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: God, and good fortune go with thee, farewell. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Well, I will goe, but not in this disguise;
Arme thee with policie Franke, Franke must be wise:
Now would the substance of this borrowed shape
Were here in presence, and see where he comes,
Poore in the well framd limbes of nature, but
Rich in kindnesse beyond comparison.
Welcome deere friend, the kindest soule aliue,
Here I resigne thy habite backe againe,
Whereby I prooue the happiest man that breaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Hast thou then, sweet blood, been fortunate?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Harke, I will tell thee all: Whisper in priuate.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Bowdler, Mall Berry, and Ralfe, Bowdler capers and sings.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralf.
SP.L: Faith sir, me thinkes of late you are very light.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: As a feather, sweet Rogue, as a feather:
Haue I not good cause, sweet Mall, sweet Mall,
Hath she not causde the same: well, if I liue, sweet wench,
Either by night or day I will requite your kindenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke.
SP.L: Now I will take my leaue, to put the same in practise. Exit Franke.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Good fortune waite on thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Mall, thou art mine, by thine owne consent;
How saist thou Mall?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Yes forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralfe.
SP.L: I am witnesse sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: But that is not sufficient Mall, if thou art content Mall, heer's a Rogue hard by, a friend of mine, whom I will acquaint with our loues, and hee shall bee partaker of the match.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralf.
SP.L: Nay sir, if you meane to haue partners in the match, I hope Ralfe can helpe to serue your wiues turne as well as an∣other, what ere he be. How say you mistresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Alls one to me, whom he please.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Come then sweet Mall, weele to the Drawer,
There to dispatch what I further intend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: And well remembred husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Ralfe.
SP.L: A forward maiden by this light; husband before the Clarke hath said Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: He hath worke of mine, I pray forget it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: I will not Mall. Now you lame Rogue, where is this maidens worke? my wiues worke you rascall, quicke, giue it her?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Sweet Seignior, the sweet Nimphes worke is almost finished, but sweete blood, you driue me into admiration with your latter words, your sweet wiues worke, I admire it!

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: I yee halting Rascall, my wiues worke; shee's my wife before God and Ralfe, how saist thou Mall, art thou not?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Yes for sooth, and to confirme the same,
Heere in this presence, I plight my faith againe;
And speake againe, what erst before was said,
That none but you shall haue my maiden-head.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: A good wench Mall, ifaith, now will I to thy fa∣ther for his good wil, Cripple, see you remember what is past, for I will call thee in question for a witnesse if neede require, farewell curre, farewell dogge. Exit. Bowdler and Ralfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: A due fond humorist, Parenthesis of iests,
Whose humour like a needlesse Cypher sils a roome:
But now Mall Berry, a word or two with you:
Hast thou forgotten Barnet? thy thoughts were bent on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: On him Cripple! for what? was it for marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: It was for loue, why not for marriage? O monstrous!
Were I a maide and should be so bewitch'd,
I'de pull my eyes out that did lend me light,
Exclaime against my fortune, banne my starres,
And teare my heart, so yeelding her consent
To Bowdlers loue, that froth of complement.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Cripple, you lose your time, with your faire teares
To circumuent my heart: Bowdler I loue thee,
Barnard I hate, and thou shalt neuer mooue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: I will; thou dost loue Barnard, and I can prooue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: That I loue Barnard! by heauens I abhorre him.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Thou lou'st him, once againe I say, thou lou'st him,
For all thou hast borne Bowdler still in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: What wilt thou make me mad? I say, I hate him.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: I say thou lou'st him: haue not I been at home,
And heard thee in thy chamber praise his person,
And say he is a proper little man,
And pray that he would be a suter to thee?
Haue I not seene thee in the Bay-window
To sit crosse-aride, take counsell of thy glasse,
And prune thy selfe to please yong Barnards eye?
Some times curling thy haire, then practising smiles,
Sometimes rubbing thy filthy butter-teeth,
Then pull the haires from off thy beetle-browes.
Painting the veins vpon thy breasts with blew,
An hundred other trickes I saw thee vse,
And all for Barnard.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: For Barnard! twas for Bowdler.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: I say, for Barnard.
Nay more, thou knowst I lay one night at home,
And in thy sleepe I heard thee call on Barnard
Twentie times ouer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Will you be sworne I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: I, I will sweare it:
And art thou not ashamde thus to be changde,
To leaue the loue of a kinde Gentleman
To dote on Bowdler? Fie, fie, reclaime thy selfe:
Imbrace thy Barnard, take him for thy husband,
And saue his credite, who is else vndone,
By thy hard fathers hatefull crueltie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: Cripple, If thou canst prooue that euer I
Did fancie Barnard, I will loue him still.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Why ile be sworne thou didst.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: And that I doated on him in my sleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Ile be sworne I could not sleepe all night
In the next roome, thou didst so raue on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: I cannot tell, I may well be deceiu'd,
I thinke I might affect him in my sleepe,
And yet not know it; let me looke on him,
Yfaith he is a pretty hansome fellow,
Tis pitty he should waste himselfe in prison;
Hey ho.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Whats the mater wench?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Cripple, I will loue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Wilt thou yfaith?

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: Yfaith I will. Enter two Serieants

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Giue me thy hand, a bargaine, tis enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.L: But how shall he know I loue him?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Why thus: I will intreate the Serieants
To goe with him along vnto thy father,
And by the way ile send yong Bowdler from vs,
And then acquaint my Barnard with thy loue,
He shall accept it and auouch the same
Vnto thy father, wench do thou the like,
And then I hope his bonds are cancelled.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: Cripple, shall we haue your company?

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: My friends, hold here, theres mony for your paines
Walke with your prisoner but to maister Berry,
And ye shall either finde sufficient baile,
Or else discharge the debt, or I assure you
Weele be your ayde to guarde him safe to prison.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Serieant
SP.L: Well, we are willing sir, we are content
To shew the Gentleman any kind of fauour.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Along then; hearke maister Bowdler. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Maister Flower, Mistris Flower, Maister Berry, and Fiddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist Flo.
SP.L: Welcome good maister Berry, is your stomack vp sir? It is a good conceit yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiddle
SP.L: It is indeede sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Master Flo.
SP.L: What, Fiddle!

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: If his stomacke be vp to goe to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Fiddle, bid maister Berry welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: What else maister? with the best belly in my heart, the sweetest straine in my musicke, and the worst entertainment that may be, Fiddle bids your worship adesdum.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: Thankes Fiddle, and maister Flower, I am much be∣holding to your curtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Fiddle, I wonder that he staies so long,
Thou toldst me Anthony would follow thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: I, and heele be heere I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Ile tell you sir, it is a rare conceit,
My wife would haue her marry Anthony,
The yonger brother, but against her minde,
I will contract her vnto Ferdinand,
And I haue sent for you and other friends,
To witnes it; and tis a good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Fiddle, are all things ordred well within?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Alls well, alls well, but there wants some saffron,
To colour the custards withall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Heere, take my keyes, bid Susan take enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Fiddle, are all our guests come yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: I sir, and here comes one more than you lookt for.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: God saue you Master Flower, as much to you Ma∣ster Berry.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Welcome M. Golding, yare very welcome sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: My brother Ferdinand commends him to you,
And heeres a letter to you from himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: A letter sir, it is a good conceit,
Ile reade it strait,
SP.STAGE: Giues the other Letter to mistris Flower.
SP.L: Maister Flower, I am beholding to you for your kindenesse, and your furtherance in my loue-suite, but my minde is chan∣ged, and I will not marry your daughter, and so farewell.
This is no good conceit: what Ferdinand,
Delude olde Flower, make me deceiue my friends,
Make my wife laugh, and triumph in her will,
What thinke you Fiddle?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Why sir I thinke it is no good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Thou saist true Fiddle, tis a bad conceit,
But heare you sir.

LETTER.P: I vnderstand by Fiddle your forwardnesse in my sute to your daughter: but neuertheles I am determined to drawe backe, and commit your daughter to her best fortunes, and your selfe to God; Farewell.

SP.L: Why this is like my husbands bad conceit,
Haue you ore-reachd me Flower, you crafty fox?
This is your doing, but for all your sleight
Ile crosse you if my purpose hit aright.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Tut, tell not me sir, for my credite and reputation is as it is, and theres an end: if I shall haue her, why so.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Flo.
SP.L: Sir, the conceit is doubtfull, giue me leaue but to consider of it by my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Maister Golding, a word I pray sir,
You know my daughter Phillis, doe you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Mistris, I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: She is a starre I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: She is no lesse indeede.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: I tell you sir vpon the sodaine now,
There came an odde conceit into my head,
Are you a batcheller?

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: I am indeede.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: And are you not promisde?

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Not yet beleeue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Maister Golding.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Well, do you heare sir? if you will be pleasde
To wed my daughter Phillis, you shall haue her.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: To wed your daughter, why she loues me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Alls one for that, she will be rulde by me:
Disdaine her not because I proffer her,
I tell you sir, Merchants of great account
Haue sought her loue, and Gentlemen of worth,
Haue humbly sude to me in that behalfe:
To say the trueth, I promisde her to one,
But I am crossd and thwarted by my husband,
Who meanes to marry hir vnto another:
Now sir, to cry but quittance for his guile,
I offer her to you; if you accept her,
Ile make her dowrie richer by a paire
Of hundred pounds than else it should haue beene.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Why this is excellent, past all compare,
Sude to to haue her, gentle mistris Flower,
Let me consider of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Nay, nay, deferre no time if you wil haue her,
Ile search my coffers for another hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Say I should yeeld, your husband will withstand it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Fl.
SP.L: Ile haue it closely done without his knowlege;
Is it a match?

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Well, well, I am content.

SP.SPEAKER: Mast. Fl.
SP.L: Why then old Flower, ile crosse your close intent.

SP.SPEAKER: Master Flo.
SP.L: It shall be so; and tis a good conceit,
It shall be so if but to crosse my wife,
Hearke maister Golding, the conceit doth like me.
You loue my daughter, so me thought you said;
You said moreouer, that she loues you well,
This loue on both sides is a good conceit.
But are you sure sir, that my daughter loues you?

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: For proofe thereof shew her this ring.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: A ring of hers! tis well.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: I but conceit mee,
If I had wood her in my proper shape,
I do beleeue she neuer would haue likde me,
Therefore since I shall haue her, giue me leaue
To come and court hir in my borrowed shape.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: With all my heart, and tis a good conceit,
And heeres my hand, sonne Golding, thou shalt haue her.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Then father Flower, I rest vpon your promise,
Ile leaue you for a while, till I put on
My counterfeited shape, and then returne. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Welcome good sonne, tis wel, by this conceit
My wife will be preuented of her will:
I would not for the halfe of all my wealth,
My crosse-word wife had compassd her intent:
Now wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Now Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: You still maintaine the sute for Anthony,
Youle haue your will, and I must breake my worde.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Flo.
SP.L: Ieast on old Flower, be crosse, and do thy worst,
Worke the best meanes thou canst, yet whiles I liue
I sweare she neuer shall wed Ferdinand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mast. Flo.
SP.L: What shall she not?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Flo.
SP.L: No that she shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Master Flo.
SP.L: I say, she shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Yfaith she shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Well wife, I am vext, and by Gods pretious.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Berry
SP.L: O sir, be patient gentle mistris Flower,
Crosse not your husband, let him haue his will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: His will!

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Hearst thou wife, be quiet, thou knowest my humor.
Thus to be crossde, it is no good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: A fig for your conceit; yet for because,
I know I shall preuent him of the match,
That he intends, henceforth I will dissemble.
Well maister Flower, because it shalbe saide,
And for kind maister Berry may report
The humble loyalty I beare to you,
Such as a wife should doe vnto her husband.
I am content to yeeld to your desires,
Protesting, whiles I liue, I neuer more
Will speake that Anthony may marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Wife, speakst thou with thy heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Husband, I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Doost thou indeede?

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flo.
SP.L: Indeede forsooth I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Then tis a good conceit: ha, ha;
I see tis sometimes good to looke aloft,
Come hither wife, because thou art so humble,
Ile tell thee all, I haue receiu'd a letter
From Ferdinand, wherein he sends me word,
He will not marry with my daughter Phillis,
And therefore I was full determined
To crosse thy purpose, that his brother Franke
Should marry her, and so I still intend:
What saist thou wife, dost thou assent thereto?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Flo.
SP.L: That Franke should marry her, I haue sworne he shall,
And since this falles so right, ile not disclose,
That I did meane so much; but now Ile yeeld,
That it may seeme my true humilitie:
Husband, because heereafter you may say,
And thinke me louing, loyall, and submisse,
I am content, Franke shall haue my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Why now thou shewst thy selfe obedient,
And thou dost please me with thy good conceit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Barnard, Mall, and two Serieants.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: By your leaue maister Flower,
Berry I am arrested at your sute.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: And I am glad of it with all my heart;
Hold friends, theres somewhat more for you to drinke,
Away with him to prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: Stay maister Berry, I haue brought you baile.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: What baile? where is your baile? heres none I know
Will bee thy baile, away with him to prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall
SP.L: Yes, I forsooth father, ile be his baile,
Body for body; thinke you ile stay at home,
And see my husband carried to the Iaile?

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: How, thy husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Mall
SP.L: My husband I assure you:
Father, these Serieants both can witnes it.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Ser.
SP.L: We saw them both contracted man and wife,
And therefore thought it fit to giue you knowledge,
Before we carried him vnto the prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: But ile vndoe this contract on my blessing,
Daughter, come from him, hee's a reprobate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall
SP.L: He is my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: But thou shalt not haue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mall
SP.L: Faith but I will, Barnard, speake for thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: Why M. Berry, tis well knowne to you,
I am a gentleman, though by misfortune,
My ventures in the world haue somewhat faild me:
Say that my wealth disables my desert,
The diffrence of our bload supplies that want?
What though my lands be morgagde, if you please,
The dowrie you intend to giue your daughter,
May well redeeme them. You perhaps imagine
I will be wilde, but I intend it not.
What shall I say, if you will giue consent?
As you redeeme my lands, so I my time ill spent
Meane to redeeme; with frugall industry,
Ile be your councells pupill, and submit
My follies to your will, mine to your wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: What thinke you maister Flower?

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Faith maister Berry,
Barnara speakes well, and with a good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal
SP.L: Doost thou loue him Mall?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall
SP.L: Yes sir, and heere protest,
Of all in London I loue Barnard best.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Then maister Berry, follow my conceit,
Cancell his bond, and let him haue your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: Well Barnard, since I see my daughter loues thee,
And for I hope thou wilt be kinde and louing,
Regard thy state, and turne an honest man,
Heere, take my daughter, ile giue thee in thy bond,
Redeeme thy landes, and if thou please me well,
Thou shalt not want all that I haue is thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Barn.
SP.L: I am loue-bound to her, to you in duety,
You conquer me with kindenesse, she with beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Ser.
SP.L: Then Maister Berry I thinke we may depart.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry
SP.L: I, when you please, you see the matter ended,
The debt dischargde, and I can aske no more.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Ser.
SP.L: Why then we take our leaues. Exeunt Serieants.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma. Flo.
SP.L: Now wife, if yong Franke Golding were come back,
To summe our wish, it were a good conceit: Enter Phi.
Why how now Phillis, sad, come tell me wench,
Art thou resolu'd yet for to haue thy husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: A golden Golding, tis a good conceit.
That golden Golding is but loath some drosse,
Nor is it golde that I so much esteeme;
Dust is the richest treasure that we haue,
Nor is the beauty of the fairest one,
Of higher price or valew vnto me,
Than is a lumpe of poore deformity.
Father, you know my minde, and what I saide,
Which if you graunt not, I will rest a maide. Enter Fid.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: To die a maide, that is no good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Master, wheres my maister? heeres one would couple a brace of words with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: With me sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: No sir, with my yong mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: What is he knaue?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: A crooked knaue sir, tis the Cripple.

SP.SPEAKER: Mai. Flo.
SP.L: What would he haue? he hath no good conceit,
Tis he that hath bewitcht my daughters heart,
He is a knaue, goe send him packing hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: As you respect the welfare of your childe,
Deere father, let me speake with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Speake with him! no, it is no good conceit,
I know hee comes to runne away with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Runne away with her? well may shee carry him, but if he runne away with her, ile neuer trust crutch more.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: Thou saist true Fiddle, tis a good conceit:
Go call him in, Franke Golding, it is he. Exit Fid.
In the lame knaues disguise, a good conceit; Enter Frank
Now sir, whats the newes with you, you come to speake with my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Franke
SP.L: Yea sir, about a little worke I haue of hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Maister Flo.
SP.L: What worke, you knaue? no, thou hast some conceit, to robbe me of my daughter; but away:
I like not that conceit out of my doores.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Vnhappy Phillis, and vnfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Sir, I am content, ile not moue your patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Life of my liuing body, if thou goe,
Though not aliue take me hence dead with woe. she sounds

SP.SPEAKER: Berry.
SP.L: In troth sir, you are too blame.

SP.SPEAKER: Master Flow.
SP.L: What? is she dead? it is no good conceit.
Speake to me Phillis, O vnhappy time,
Sweete Girle, deere daughter, O my onely ioy,
Speake to thy father wench, in some conceit,
What, not a word?

SP.SPEAKER: Berry.
SP.L: Now may you see, what fell impatience
Begets vpon such tender plants as these.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistris Flow.
SP.L: Now may we see the folly of old age,
Gouern'd by spleene, and ouerweening rage.

SP.SPEAKER: Master Flow.
SP.L: Speake to me, daughter.
And thou shalt haue, what not? couetst thou gold?
Thou shalt not want for crownes, thou shalt haue all.
O was my furie author of thy trance?
Did I deny thy loues accesse to thee?
Speake but one word and thou shalt be his wife,
By heauen thou shalt.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: I take you at your word; it is no paine
To die for loue, and then reuiue againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Berry.
SP.L: Now M. Flower how like you this conceit,
Hath shee not ouer reach'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Flow.
SP.L: My word is past, and yet for all my rage,
I rather choose to faile in my conceit,
And wed thee Phillis to thy owne content.
Heere, take my daughter, Cripple, loue her well,
Be kinde to her, and ile be kinde to thee,
Thou art but poore, well I will make thee rich,
And so God blesse you, with a good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I thanke you, when I leaue to loue my wife,
Heauen hasten death and take away my life.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Flow.
SP.L: Tis well done Franke, I applaude thy wit,
And now I know I faile not in conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Crip.
SP.L: Gentlemen sweet bloods, or brethren of familiarity,
I would speake with Phillis, shall I haue audience?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Helpe me derre father, O helpe me Gentlemen,
This is some spirit, driue him from my sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Were he the deuill, thou shalt not budge a foote.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Zounds two Cripples, two dogs two curres, tis won∣derfull!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Feare not deare heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Hence foule deformitie.
Nor thou nor he, shall my companion be,
If Cripples dead, the liuing seeme to haunt,
Ile neither of either, therefore I say auaunt;
Helpe, me father.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Deere heart, reuoke these words,
Here are no spirites nor deformities,
I am a counterfeit Cripple now no more,
But yong Franke Golaing. as I was before:
Amaze not loue, nor seeme not discontent,
Nor thee nor him shall euer this repent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: M. Flower, I come to claime your promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: I come for yours, your daughter I doe meane.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Flow.
SP.L: My promise; why sir, you refusde my promise,
And sent me word so in your letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mistresse Flow.
SP.L: And so did you to me, and now tis past,
Your brother Franke hath both our free consents.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Sir, sir, I wrote no letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: By heauen, nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: But I did for you both; I was your Scribe,
The whilst you went to see your house a fire:
And you (as I remember) I did send,
To see your sister drown'd at London-Bridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Y faith good brother haue you ore reach,d vs so?

SP.SPEAKER: Anth,
SP.L: So cunningly, that none of vs could know.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: For all this cunning, I will breake the match.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: And so will I.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Why brothers, shee's mine by her fathers gift.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Brother you lie, you got her with a shift.

SP.SPEAKER: Franke.
SP.L: I was the first that lou'd her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: That's not so, t'was I.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Catch that catch can, then brothers both you lie.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Flow.
SP.P:
Yea, but conceit me Gentlemen, what doe you
meane to spoile my daughter? you claime her, and I haue gi∣uen her your yonger brother; this is no good conceite: why how now Phillis, still drooping, cheare thee my girle, see a companie of Gentlemen are at strife for thy loue; looke vp, and in this faire assembly make thine owne choise; choose where thou wilt, and vse thine owne conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: But will my father then applaud my choise?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Flow.
SP.L: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: And will these worthy Gentlemen be pleasde,
How euer my dislike or liking prooue?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: We will.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: I must confesse you all haue taken paines,
And I can giue but all for that paines taken,
And all my all, is but a little loue,
And of a little who can make deuision,
I would I knew what would content you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Thy loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Anoth.
SP.L: Thy life and loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Thy life, thy loue, thy selfe, and all for me,
For if I want but one, I then want thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: If then I giue what either if you craue,
Though not what you desire will it suffice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: I wish but loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: And as a friend you haue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: I life and loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: And as your friend, I vow, to loue you whilst I liue, as doe now.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I aske but all for I deserue no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: And thou shalt haue thy wish, take all my store,
My loue my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: By heauen, I aske no more:
Brothers, haue done, and Dad to end all strife,
Come take her hand and giue her for my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: M Flow.
SP.L: Withall my heart, and tis a good conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Gentlemen, patience is your fairest play.

SP.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SP.L: Impatience puls me hence, for this disdaine,
I am resolu'd neuer to loue againe. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.L: Stay brother Ferdinand, ile follow thee,
Farewell all loue, tis full of treacherie. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bow.
SP.L: By heauens Franke I do commend thy wit,
Come Mall, shall thou and I aske blessing too for company?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: You and I sir, alas, we are not play-fellowes, though we be turtles: I am prouided.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Prouided! why am not I thy Menelaus?

SP.SPEAKER: Mall.
SP.L: I sir, but this is my Paris, I am resolu'd,
And what I doe is by authoritie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bowd.
SP.L: Is it euen so, is Hellen stolne by Paris?
Then thus in armes will Menelaus mourne,
Till Troy be sack'd, and Hellena returne. Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.L: This is the man, officers attach him vpon fellonie.

SP.SPEAKER: Office.
SP.L: M. Flower, I arrest you vpon fellonie, and charge you to obey.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Flow.
SP.L: Arrest me vpon fellonie! at whose sute?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.L: Sir, at mine; where had you that Dyamond on your finger? it was stole from me, and many other Iewels to the va∣lue of a hundred pownd.

SP.SPEAKER: M Flo.
SP.L: This is no good conceit; hath Captaine Racket,
Banded old Flower to such an exegent?
I hope my credit somewhat will asist me;
Well, whither must I goe?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.L: Straight to the bench, where now the Iudges are
To giue you speedy tryall.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Flow.
SP.L: Words here are little worth, wife and friends all
Goe with me to my tryall, you shall see
A good conceit now brought to infamie. Exeunt.
